Need help reading this?

elastic-builder

https://github.com/sudo-suhas/elastic-builder

elastic-builder is a library for easily building elasticsearch request body for search. It implements the builder syntax for building complex queries combining queries and aggregations.

What's Included:

  • Request Body Search
  • Queries
  • Aggregations
  • Suggesters
  • Search Template

The complete library documentation is present here.

There are two ways to use the classes for constructing queries:

// Import the library
const esb = require('elastic-builder'); // the builder

// Use `new` keyword for constructor instances of class
const requestBody = new esb.RequestBodySearch()
    .query(new esb.MatchQuery('message', 'this is a test'));

// Or use helper methods which construct the object without need for the `new` keyword
const requestBody = esb.requestBodySearch()
    .query(esb.matchQuery('message', 'this is a test'));

// Build the request body
requestBody.toJSON()
{
   "query": {
     "match": {
       "message": "this is a test"
     }
   }
 }

Demo - https://elastic-builder.js.org/

ProTip: The source is transpiled using babel for compatibility with older versions of node and used by default. But this is not required in node env 6 and above. You can directly use the src files:

const esb = require('elastic-builder/src');

This module is heavily influenced by elastic.js(not maintained anymore).

elastic-builder

https://github.com/sudo-suhas/elastic-builder

elastic-builder is a library for easily building elasticsearch request body for search. It implements the builder syntax for building complex queries combining queries and aggregations.

What's Included:

  • Request Body Search
  • Queries
  • Aggregations
  • Suggesters
  • Search Template

The complete library documentation is present here.

There are two ways to use the classes for constructing queries:

// Import the library
const esb = require('elastic-builder'); // the builder

// Use `new` keyword for constructor instances of class
const requestBody = new esb.RequestBodySearch()
    .query(new esb.MatchQuery('message', 'this is a test'));

// Or use helper methods which construct the object without need for the `new` keyword
const requestBody = esb.requestBodySearch()
    .query(esb.matchQuery('message', 'this is a test'));

// Build the request body
requestBody.toJSON()
{
   "query": {
     "match": {
       "message": "this is a test"
     }
   }
 }

Demo - https://elastic-builder.js.org/

ProTip: The source is transpiled using babel for compatibility with older versions of node and used by default. But this is not required in node env 6 and above. You can directly use the src files:

const esb = require('elastic-builder/src');

This module is heavily influenced by elastic.js(not maintained anymore).

RequestBodySearch

src/core/request-body-search.js

The RequestBodySearch object provides methods generating an elasticsearch search request body. The search request can be executed with a search DSL, which includes the Query DSL, within its body.

Elasticsearch reference

new RequestBodySearch()
Example
const reqBody = esb.requestBodySearch()
    .query(esb.termQuery('user', 'kimchy'))
    .from(0)
    .size(10);

reqBody.toJSON();
{
  "query": { "term": { "user": "kimchy" } },
  "from": 0,
  "size": 10
}
// Query and aggregation
const reqBody = esb.requestBodySearch()
    .query(esb.matchQuery('business_type', 'shop'))
    .agg(
        esb.geoBoundsAggregation('viewport', 'location').wrapLongitude(true)
    );
// Query, aggregation with nested
const reqBody = esb.requestBodySearch()
    .query(esb.matchQuery('crime', 'burglary'))
    .agg(
        esb.termsAggregation('towns', 'town').agg(
            esb.geoCentroidAggregation('centroid', 'location')
        )
    );
Instance Members
▸ query(query)
src/core/request-body-search.js

Define query on the search request body using the Query DSL.

query(query: Query): RequestBodySearch
Parameters
query (Query)
Returns
RequestBodySearch: returns this so that calls can be chained.

▸ aggregations(aggs)
src/core/request-body-search.js

Sets multiple nested aggregation items. This method accepts an array to set multiple nested aggregations in one call.

aggregations(aggs: Array<Aggregation>): Aggregation
Parameters
aggs (Array<Aggregation>) Array of valid Aggregation items
Returns
Aggregation: returns this so that calls can be chained.
Throws

  • TypeError: If aggs contains instances not of type Aggregation
▸ suggest(suggest)
src/core/request-body-search.js

Sets suggester on the request body.

suggest(suggest: Suggester): RequestBodySearch
Parameters
suggest (Suggester) Any valid Suggester
Returns
RequestBodySearch: returns this so that calls can be chained.
Throws
  • TypeError: If suggest is not an instance of Suggester
Example
const req = esb.requestBodySearch()
    .query(esb.matchQuery('message', 'trying out elasticsearch'))
    .suggest(
        esb.termSuggester(
            'my-suggestion',
            'message',
            'tring out Elasticsearch'
        )
    );
▸ suggestText(txt)
src/core/request-body-search.js

Sets the global suggest text to avoid repetition for multiple suggestions.

suggestText(txt: string): RequestBodySearch
Parameters
txt (string) Global suggest text
Returns
RequestBodySearch: returns this so that calls can be chained.
Example
const req = esb.requestBodySearch()
    .suggestText('tring out elasticsearch')
    .suggest(esb.termSuggester('my-suggest-1', 'message'))
    .suggest(esb.termSuggester('my-suggest-2', 'user'));
▸ timeout(timeout)
src/core/request-body-search.js

Sets a search timeout, bounding the search request to be executed within the specified time value and bail with the hits accumulated up to that point when expired.

timeout(timeout: string): RequestBodySearch
Parameters
timeout (string) Duration can be specified using time units Defaults to no timeout.
Returns
RequestBodySearch: returns this so that calls can be chained.
▸ from(from)
src/core/request-body-search.js

To retrieve hits from a certain offset.

from(from: number): RequestBodySearch
Parameters
from (number) Defaults to 0.
Returns
RequestBodySearch: returns this so that calls can be chained.
▸ size(size)
src/core/request-body-search.js

The number of hits to return. If you do not care about getting some hits back but only about the number of matches and/or aggregations, setting the value to 0 will help performance.

size(size: number): RequestBodySearch
Parameters
size (number) Defaults to 10.
Returns
RequestBodySearch: returns this so that calls can be chained.
▸ terminateAfter(numberOfDocs)
src/core/request-body-search.js

The maximum number of documents to collect for each shard, upon reaching which the query execution will terminate early. If set, the response will have a boolean field terminated_early to indicate whether the query execution has actually terminated early.

terminateAfter(numberOfDocs: number): RequestBodySearch
Parameters
numberOfDocs (number) Maximum number of documents to collect for each shard. Defaults to no limit.
Returns
RequestBodySearch: returns this so that calls can be chained.
▸ sort(sort)
src/core/request-body-search.js

Allows to add sort on specific field. The sort can be reversed as well. The sort is defined on a per field level, with special field name for _score to sort by score, and _doc to sort by index order.

sort(sort: Sort): RequestBodySearch
Parameters
sort (Sort)
Returns
RequestBodySearch: returns this so that calls can be chained.
Throws
  • TypeError: If parameter sort is not an instance of Sort .
Example
const reqBody = esb.requestBodySearch()
    .query(esb.termQuery('user', 'kimchy'))
    .sort(esb.sort('post_date', 'asc'))
    .sort(esb.sort('user'))
    .sorts([
        esb.sort('name', 'desc'),
        esb.sort('age', 'desc'),
        esb.sort('_score')
    ]);
▸ sorts(sorts)
src/core/request-body-search.js

Allows to add multiple sort on specific fields. Each sort can be reversed as well. The sort is defined on a per field level, with special field name for _score to sort by score, and _doc to sort by index order.

sorts(sorts: Array<Sort>): RequestBodySearch
Parameters
sorts (Array<Sort>) Arry of sort
Returns
RequestBodySearch: returns this so that calls can be chained.
Throws
  • TypeError: If any item in parameter sorts is not an instance of Sort .
Example
const reqBody = esb.requestBodySearch()
    .query(esb.termQuery('user', 'kimchy'))
    .sort(esb.sort('post_date', 'asc'))
    .sort(esb.sort('user'))
    .sorts([
        esb.sort('name', 'desc'),
        esb.sort('age', 'desc'),
        esb.sort('_score')
    ]);
▸ trackScores(enable)
src/core/request-body-search.js

When sorting on a field, scores are not computed. By setting track_scores to true, scores will still be computed and tracked.

trackScores(enable: boolean): RequestBodySearch
Parameters
enable (boolean)
Returns
RequestBodySearch: returns this so that calls can be chained
Example
const reqBody = esb.requestBodySearch()
    .trackScores(true)
    .sorts([
        esb.sort('post_date', 'desc'),
        esb.sort('name', 'desc'),
        esb.sort('age', 'desc')
    ])
    .query(esb.termQuery('user', 'kimchy'));
▸ trackTotalHits(enableOrLimit)
src/core/request-body-search.js

The track_total_hits parameter allows you to control how the total number of hits should be tracked. Passing false can increase performance in some situations. (Added in elasticsearch@7)

Pass true, false, or the upper limit (default: 10000) of hits you want tracked.

trackTotalHits(enableOrLimit: (boolean | number)): RequestBodySearch
Parameters
enableOrLimit ((boolean | number))
Returns
RequestBodySearch: returns this so that calls can be chained
▸ source(source)
src/core/request-body-search.js

Allows to control how the _source field is returned with every hit. You can turn off _source retrieval by passing false. It also accepts one(string) or more wildcard(array) patterns to control what parts of the _source should be returned An object can also be used to specify the wildcard patterns for includes and excludes.

source(source: (boolean | string | Array | Object)): RequestBodySearch
Parameters
source ((boolean | string | Array | Object))
Returns
RequestBodySearch: returns this so that calls can be chained
Example
// To disable `_source` retrieval set to `false`:
const reqBody = esb.requestBodySearch()
    .query(esb.termQuery('user', 'kimchy'))
    .source(false);
// The `_source` also accepts one or more wildcard patterns to control what
// parts of the `_source` should be returned:
const reqBody = esb.requestBodySearch()
    .query(esb.termQuery('user', 'kimchy'))
    .source('obj.*');

// OR
const reqBody = esb.requestBodySearch()
    .query(esb.termQuery('user', 'kimchy'))
    .source([ 'obj1.*', 'obj2.*' ]);
// For complete control, you can specify both `includes` and `excludes` patterns:
const reqBody = esb.requestBodySearch()
    .query(esb.termQuery('user', 'kimchy'))
    .source({
        'includes': [ 'obj1.*', 'obj2.*' ],
        'excludes': [ '*.description' ]
    });
▸ storedFields(fields)
src/core/request-body-search.js

The stored_fields parameter is about fields that are explicitly marked as stored in the mapping. Selectively load specific stored fields for each document represented by a search hit using array of stored fields. An empty array will cause only the _id and _type for each hit to be returned. To disable the stored fields (and metadata fields) entirely use: _none_

storedFields(fields: (Array | string)): RequestBodySearch
Parameters
fields ((Array | string))
Returns
RequestBodySearch: returns this so that calls can be chained
Example
// Selectively load specific stored fields for each document
// represented by a search hit
const reqBody = esb.requestBodySearch()
    .query(esb.termQuery('user', 'kimchy'))
    .storedFields(['user', 'postDate']);
// Return only the `_id` and `_type` to be returned:
const reqBody = esb.requestBodySearch()
    .query(esb.termQuery('user', 'kimchy'))
    .storedFields([]);
// Disable the stored fields (and metadata fields) entirely
const reqBody = esb.requestBodySearch()
    .query(esb.termQuery('user', 'kimchy'))
    .storedFields('_none_');
▸ runtimeMapping(runtimeFieldName, runtimeField)
src/core/request-body-search.js

Computes a document property dynamically based on the supplied runtimeField.

Elasticsearch reference

Added in Elasticsearch v7.11.0 Release note

runtimeMapping(runtimeFieldName: string, runtimeField: RuntimeField): RequestBodySearch
Parameters
runtimeFieldName (string) Name for the computed runtime mapping field.
runtimeField (RuntimeField) Instance of RuntimeField
Returns
RequestBodySearch: returns this so that calls can be chained
Example
const reqBody = esb.requestBodySearch()
    .query(esb.matchAllQuery())
    .runtimeMapping(
      'sessionId-name',
      esb.runtimeField(
        'keyword',
        `emit(doc['session_id'].value + '::' + doc['name'].value)`
      )
    )
// runtime fields can also be used in query aggregation
const reqBody = esb.requestBodySearch()
    .query(esb.matchAllQuery())
    .runtimeMapping(
      'sessionId-eventName',
      esb.runtimeField(
        'keyword',
        `emit(doc['session_id'].value + '::' + doc['eventName'].value)`,
      )
    )
    .agg(esb.cardinalityAggregation('uniqueCount', `sessionId-eventName`)),;
▸ runtimeMappings(runtimeMappings)
src/core/request-body-search.js

Computes one or more document properties dynamically based on supplied RuntimeFields.

Elasticsearch reference

Added in Elasticsearch v7.11.0 Release note

runtimeMappings(runtimeMappings: Object): RequestBodySearch
Parameters
runtimeMappings (Object) Object with runtimeFieldName as key and instance of RuntimeField as the value.
Returns
RequestBodySearch: returns this so that calls can be chained
Example
const fieldA = esb.runtimeField(
      'keyword',
      `emit(doc['session_id'].value + '::' + doc['name'].value)`
);
const reqBody = esb.requestBodySearch()
    .query(esb.matchAllQuery())
    .runtimeMappings({
      'sessionId-name': fieldA,
    })
▸ scriptField(scriptFieldName, script)
src/core/request-body-search.js

Computes a document property dynamically based on the supplied Script.

scriptField(scriptFieldName: string, script: (string | Script)): RequestBodySearch
Parameters
scriptFieldName (string)
script ((string | Script)) string or instance of Script
Returns
RequestBodySearch: returns this so that calls can be chained
Example
const reqBody = esb.requestBodySearch()
    .query(esb.matchAllQuery())
    .scriptField(
        'test1',
        esb.script('inline', "doc['my_field_name'].value * 2").lang('painless')
    )
    .scriptField(
        'test2',
        esb.script('inline', "doc['my_field_name'].value * factor")
            .lang('painless')
            .params({ factor: 2.0 })
    );
// Script fields can also access the actual `_source` document and extract
// specific elements to be returned from it by using `params['_source']`.
const reqBody = esb.requestBodySearch()
    .query(esb.matchAllQuery())
    .scriptField('test1', "params['_source']['message']");
▸ scriptFields(scriptFields)
src/core/request-body-search.js

Sets given dynamic document properties to be computed using supplied Scripts.

Object should have scriptFieldName as key and script as the value.

scriptFields(scriptFields: Object): TopHitsAggregation
Parameters
scriptFields (Object) Object with scriptFieldName as key and script as the value.
Returns
TopHitsAggregation: returns this so that calls can be chained
Example
const reqBody = esb.requestBodySearch()
    .query(esb.matchAllQuery())
    .scriptFields({
        test1: esb
            .script('inline', "doc['my_field_name'].value * 2")
            .lang('painless'),
        test2: esb
            .script('inline', "doc['my_field_name'].value * factor")
            .lang('painless')
            .params({ factor: 2.0 })
    });
// Script fields can also access the actual `_source` document and extract
// specific elements to be returned from it by using `params['_source']`.
const reqBody = esb.requestBodySearch()
    .query(esb.matchAllQuery())
    .scriptFields({ test1: "params['_source']['message']" });
▸ docvalueFields(fields)
src/core/request-body-search.js

Allows to return the doc value representation of a field for each hit. Doc value fields can work on fields that are not stored.

docvalueFields(fields: Array<string>): RequestBodySearch
Parameters
fields (Array<string>)
Returns
RequestBodySearch: returns this so that calls can be chained
Example
const reqBody = esb.requestBodySearch()
    .query(esb.matchAllQuery())
    .docvalueFields(['test1', 'test2']);
▸ postFilter(filterQuery)
src/core/request-body-search.js

The post_filter is applied to the search hits at the very end of a search request, after aggregations have already been calculated.

postFilter(filterQuery: Query): RequestBodySearch
Parameters
filterQuery (Query) The filter to be applied after aggregation.
Returns
RequestBodySearch: returns this so that calls can be chained
Example
const reqBody = esb.requestBodySearch()
    .query(esb.boolQuery().filter(esb.termQuery('brand', 'gucci')))
    .agg(esb.termsAggregation('colors', 'color'))
    .agg(
        esb.filterAggregation(
            'color_red',
            esb.termQuery('color', 'red')
        ).agg(esb.termsAggregation('models', 'model'))
    )
    .postFilter(esb.termQuery('color', 'red'));
▸ highlight(highlight)
src/core/request-body-search.js

Allows to highlight search results on one or more fields. The implementation uses either the lucene plain highlighter, the fast vector highlighter (fvh) or postings highlighter.

Note: The postings highlighter has been removed in elasticsearch 6.0. The unified highlighter outputs the same highlighting when index_options is set to offsets.

highlight(highlight: Highlight): RequestBodySearch
Parameters
highlight (Highlight)
Returns
RequestBodySearch: returns this so that calls can be chained
Example
const reqBody = esb.requestBodySearch()
    .query(esb.matchAllQuery())
    .highlight(esb.highlight('content'));
const reqBody = esb.requestBodySearch()
    .query(
        esb.percolateQuery('query', 'doctype').document({
            message: 'The quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog'
        })
    )
    .highlight(esb.highlight('message'));
▸ rescore(rescore)
src/core/request-body-search.js

Rescoring can help to improve precision by reordering just the top (eg 100 - 500) documents returned by the query and post_filter phases, using a secondary (usually more costly) algorithm, instead of applying the costly algorithm to all documents in the index.

rescore(rescore: Rescore): RequestBodySearch
Parameters
rescore (Rescore)
Returns
RequestBodySearch: returns this so that calls can be chained
Throws
  • TypeError: If query is not an instance of Rescore
Example
const reqBody = esb.requestBodySearch()
    .query(esb.matchQuery('message', 'the quick brown').operator('or'))
    .rescore(
        esb.rescore(
            50,
            esb.matchPhraseQuery('message', 'the quick brown').slop(2)
        )
            .queryWeight(0.7)
            .rescoreQueryWeight(1.2)
    );
const reqBody = esb.requestBodySearch()
    .query(esb.matchQuery('message', 'the quick brown').operator('or'))
    .rescore(
        esb.rescore(
            100,
            esb.matchPhraseQuery('message', 'the quick brown').slop(2)
        )
            .queryWeight(0.7)
            .rescoreQueryWeight(1.2)
    )
    .rescore(
        esb.rescore(
            10,
            esb.functionScoreQuery().function(
                esb.scriptScoreFunction(
                    esb.script('inline', 'Math.log10(doc.likes.value + 2)')
                )
            )
        ).scoreMode('multiply')
    );
▸ explain(enable)
src/core/request-body-search.js

Enables explanation for each hit on how its score was computed.

explain(enable: boolean): RequestBodySearch
Parameters
enable (boolean)
Returns
RequestBodySearch: returns this so that calls can be chained
Example
const reqBody = esb.requestBodySearch()
    .query(esb.termQuery('user', 'kimchy'))
    .explain(true);
▸ version(enable)
src/core/request-body-search.js

Returns a version for each search hit.

version(enable: boolean): RequestBodySearch
Parameters
enable (boolean)
Returns
RequestBodySearch: returns this so that calls can be chained.
Example
const reqBody = esb.requestBodySearch()
    .query(esb.termQuery('user', 'kimchy'))
    .version(true);
▸ indexBoost(index, boost)
src/core/request-body-search.js

Allows to configure different boost level per index when searching across more than one indices. This is very handy when hits coming from one index matter more than hits coming from another index.

Alias for method indicesBoost.

indexBoost(index: string, boost: number): RequestBodySearch
Parameters
index (string) Index windcard expression or alias
boost (number)
Returns
RequestBodySearch: returns this so that calls can be chained.
Example
const reqBody = esb.requestBodySearch()
    .indexBoost('alias1', 1.4)
    .indexBoost('index*', 1.3);
▸ indicesBoost(index, boost)
src/core/request-body-search.js

Allows to configure different boost level per index when searching across more than one indices. This is very handy when hits coming from one index matter more than hits coming from another index.

indicesBoost(index: string, boost: number): RequestBodySearch
Parameters
index (string) Index windcard expression or alias
boost (number)
Returns
RequestBodySearch: returns this so that calls can be chained.
Example
const reqBody = esb.requestBodySearch()
    .indicesBoost('alias1', 1.4)
    .indicesBoost('index*', 1.3);
▸ minScore(score)
src/core/request-body-search.js

Exclude documents which have a _score less than the minimum specified in min_score.

minScore(score: number): RequestBodySearch
Parameters
score (number)
Returns
RequestBodySearch: returns this so that calls can be chained.
Example
const reqBody = esb.requestBodySearch()
    .query(esb.termQuery('user', 'kimchy'))
    .minScore(0.5);
▸ collapse(field, innerHits?, maxConcurrentGroupRequests?)
src/core/request-body-search.js

Allows to collapse search results based on field values. The collapsing is done by selecting only the top sorted document per collapse key.

The field used for collapsing must be a single valued keyword or numeric field with doc_values activated

collapse(field: string, innerHits: InnerHits?, maxConcurrentGroupRequests: number?): RequestBodySearch
Parameters
field (string)
innerHits (InnerHits?) Allows to expand each collapsed top hits.
maxConcurrentGroupRequests (number?) The number of concurrent requests allowed to retrieve the inner_hits' per group
Returns
RequestBodySearch: returns this so that calls can be chained.
Throws
  • TypeError: If innerHits is not an instance of InnerHits
Example
const reqBody = esb.requestBodySearch()
    .query(esb.matchQuery('message', 'elasticsearch'))
    .collapse('user')
    .sort(esb.sort('likes'))
    .from(10);
// Expand each collapsed top hits with the `inner_hits` option:
const reqBody = esb.requestBodySearch()
    .query(esb.matchQuery('message', 'elasticsearch'))
    .collapse(
        'user',
        esb.innerHits('last_tweets')
            .size(5)
            .sort(esb.sort('date', 'asc')),
        4
    )
    .sort(esb.sort('likes'))
    .from(10);
▸ searchAfter(values)
src/core/request-body-search.js

Allows to use the results from the previous page to help the retrieval of the next page. The search_after parameter provides a live cursor.

The parameter from must be set to 0 (or -1) when search_after is used.

searchAfter(values: Array<any>): RequestBodySearch
Parameters
values (Array<any>) The sort values of the last document to retrieve the next page of results
Returns
RequestBodySearch: returns this so that calls can be chained.
Example
const reqBody = esb.requestBodySearch()
    .size(10)
    .query(esb.matchQuery('message', 'elasticsearch'))
    .searchAfter(1463538857, 'tweet#654323')
    .sorts([esb.sort('date', 'asc'), esb.sort('_uid', 'desc')]);
▸ toJSON()
src/core/request-body-search.js

Override default toJSON to return DSL representation for the request body search

toJSON(): Object
Returns
Object: returns an Object which maps to the elasticsearch query DSL

Queries

These classes allow creation and manipulation of objects which map to elasticsearch DSL for queries.

Queries

These classes allow creation and manipulation of objects which map to elasticsearch DSL for queries.

Query

src/core/query.js

Base class implementation for all query types.

NOTE: Instantiating this directly should not be required. However, if you wish to add a custom implementation for whatever reason, this class should be extended and used, as validation against the class type is present in various places.

new Query(queryType: string)
Parameters
queryType (string)
Instance Members
▸ boost(factor)
src/core/query.js

Sets the boost value for documents matching the Query.

boost(factor: number): Query
Parameters
factor (number)
Returns
Query: returns this so that calls can be chained.
▸ name(name)
src/core/query.js

Sets the query name.

name(name: string): Query
Parameters
name (string)
Returns
Query: returns this so that calls can be chained.
Example
const boolQry = esb.boolQuery()
    .should([
        esb.matchQuery('name.first', 'shay').name('first'),
        esb.matchQuery('name.last', 'banon').name('last')
    ])
    .filter(esb.termsQuery('name.last', ['banon', 'kimchy']).name('test'));
▸ getDSL()
src/core/query.js

Build and returns DSL representation of the Query class instance.

getDSL(): Object
Returns
Object: returns an Object which maps to the elasticsearch query DSL
▸ toJSON()
src/core/query.js

Override default toJSON to return DSL representation for the query

toJSON(): Object
Returns
Object: returns an Object which maps to the elasticsearch query DSL

MatchAllQuery

src/queries/match-all-query.js

The most simple query, which matches all documents, giving them all a _score of 1.0.

Elasticsearch reference

new MatchAllQuery()

Extends Query

Example
const qry = esb.matchAllQuery().boost(1.2);

MatchNoneQuery

src/queries/match-none-query.js

The inverse of the match_all query, which matches no documents.

Elasticsearch reference

new MatchNoneQuery()

Extends Query

Example
const qry = esb.matchNoneQuery();

Full Text Queries

Full Text Queries

FullTextQueryBase

src/queries/full-text-queries/full-text-query-base.js

The FullTextQueryBase provides support for common options used across various full text query implementations.

NOTE: Instantiating this directly should not be required. However, if you wish to add a custom implementation for whatever reason, this class could be extended.

new FullTextQueryBase(queryType: string, queryString: string?)

Extends Query

Parameters
queryType (string)
queryString (string?) The query string
Instance Members
▸ analyzer(analyzer)
src/queries/full-text-queries/full-text-query-base.js

Set the analyzer to control which analyzer will perform the analysis process on the text

analyzer(analyzer: string): FullTextQueryBase
Parameters
analyzer (string)
Returns
FullTextQueryBase: returns this so that calls can be chained.
Example
const qry = esb.matchPhraseQuery('message', 'this is a test')
    .analyzer('my_analyzer');
const qry = esb.multiMatchQuery(['first', 'last', '*.edge'], 'Jon')
    .type('cross_fields')
    .analyzer('standard');
▸ minimumShouldMatch(minimumShouldMatch)
src/queries/full-text-queries/full-text-query-base.js

Sets the value controlling how many "should" clauses in the resulting boolean query should match. It can be an absolute value (2), a percentage (30%) or a combination of both. For Common Terms Query when specifying different minimum_should_match for low and high frequency terms, an object with the keys low_freq and high_freq can be used.

minimumShouldMatch(minimumShouldMatch: (string | number | Object)): FullTextQueryBase
Parameters
minimumShouldMatch ((string | number | Object)) Note: Object notation can only be used with Common Terms Query.
Returns
FullTextQueryBase: returns this so that calls can be chained.
Example
const qry = esb.commonTermsQuery('body', 'nelly the elephant as a cartoon')
    .minimumShouldMatch(2)
    .cutoffFrequency(0.001);
▸ query(queryString)
src/queries/full-text-queries/full-text-query-base.js

Sets the query string.

query(queryString: string): FullTextQueryBase
Parameters
queryString (string)
Returns
FullTextQueryBase: returns this so that calls can be chained.
Example
const qry = esb.queryStringQuery()
    .query('city.\\*:(this AND that OR thus)')
    .useDisMax(true);

MonoFieldQueryBase

src/queries/full-text-queries/mono-field-query-base.js

The MonoFieldQueryBase provides support for common options used across various full text query implementations with single search field.

NOTE: Instantiating this directly should not be required. However, if you wish to add a custom implementation for whatever reason, this class could be extended.

new MonoFieldQueryBase(queryType: string, field: string?, queryString: string?)

Extends FullTextQueryBase

Parameters
queryType (string)
field (string?) The document field to query against
queryString (string?) The query string
Instance Members
▸ field(field)
src/queries/full-text-queries/mono-field-query-base.js

Sets the field to search on.

field(field: string): MonoFieldQueryBase
Parameters
field (string)
Returns
MonoFieldQueryBase: returns this so that calls can be chained.
▸ toJSON()
src/queries/full-text-queries/mono-field-query-base.js

Override default toJSON to return DSL representation of the Full text query class instance.

toJSON(): Object
Returns
Object: returns an Object which maps to the elasticsearch query DSL

MatchQuery

src/queries/full-text-queries/match-query.js

match query accepts text/numerics/dates, analyzes them, and constructs a query.

Elasticsearch reference

new MatchQuery(field: string?, queryString: string?)

Extends MonoFieldQueryBase

Parameters
field (string?) The document field to query against
queryString (string?) The query string
Example
const matchQry = esb.matchQuery('message', 'to be or not to be');
// Providing additional parameters:
const qry = esb.matchQuery('message', 'this is a test').operator('and');
Instance Members
▸ operator(operator)
src/queries/full-text-queries/match-query.js

The operator to be used in the boolean query which is constructed by analyzing the text provided. The operator flag can be set to or or and to control the boolean clauses (defaults to or).

operator(operator: string): MatchQuery
Parameters
operator (string) Can be and / or . Default is or .
Returns
MatchQuery: returns this so that calls can be chained.
▸ lenient(enable)
src/queries/full-text-queries/match-query.js

Sets the lenient parameter which allows to ignore exceptions caused by data-type mismatches such as trying to query a numeric field with a text query string when set to true.

lenient(enable: boolean): MatchQuery
Parameters
enable (boolean) Defaules to false
Returns
MatchQuery: returns this so that calls can be chained.
▸ fuzziness(factor)
src/queries/full-text-queries/match-query.js

Sets the fuzziness parameter which is interpreted as a Levenshtein Edit Distance — the number of one character changes that need to be made to one string to make it the same as another string.

fuzziness(factor: (number | string)): MatchQuery
Parameters
factor ((number | string)) Can be specified either as a number, or the maximum number of edits, or as AUTO which generates an edit distance based on the length of the term.
Returns
MatchQuery: returns this so that calls can be chained.
▸ prefixLength(len)
src/queries/full-text-queries/match-query.js

Sets the prefix length for a fuzzy prefix MatchQuery

prefixLength(len: number): MatchQuery
Parameters
len (number)
Returns
MatchQuery: returns this so that calls can be chained.
▸ maxExpansions(limit)
src/queries/full-text-queries/match-query.js

Sets the max expansions for a fuzzy prefix MatchQuery

maxExpansions(limit: number): MatchQuery
Parameters
limit (number)
Returns
MatchQuery: returns this so that calls can be chained.
▸ rewrite(method)
src/queries/full-text-queries/match-query.js

Sets the rewrite method. Valid values are:

  • constant_score - tries to pick the best constant-score rewrite method based on term and document counts from the query. Synonyms - constant_score_auto, constant_score_filter

  • scoring_boolean - translates each term into boolean should and keeps the scores as computed by the query

  • constant_score_boolean - same as scoring_boolean, expect no scores are computed.

  • constant_score_filter - first creates a private Filter, by visiting each term in sequence and marking all docs for that term

  • top_terms_boost_N - first translates each term into boolean should and scores are only computed as the boost using the top N scoring terms. Replace N with an integer value.

  • top_terms_N - first translates each term into boolean should and keeps the scores as computed by the query. Only the top N scoring terms are used. Replace N with an integer value.

Default is constant_score.

Note: The deprecated multi term rewrite parameters constant_score_auto, constant_score_filter (synonyms for constant_score) have been removed in elasticsearch 6.0.

This is an advanced option, use with care.

rewrite(method: string): MatchQuery
Parameters
method (string) The rewrite method as a string.
Returns
MatchQuery: returns this so that calls can be chained.
Throws
  • Error: If the given rewrite method is not valid.
▸ fuzzyRewrite(method)
src/queries/full-text-queries/match-query.js

Sets the fuzzy rewrite method. Valid values are:

  • constant_score - tries to pick the best constant-score rewrite method based on term and document counts from the query. Synonyms - constant_score_auto, constant_score_filter

  • scoring_boolean - translates each term into boolean should and keeps the scores as computed by the query

  • constant_score_boolean - same as scoring_boolean, expect no scores are computed.

  • constant_score_filter - first creates a private Filter, by visiting each term in sequence and marking all docs for that term

  • top_terms_boost_N - first translates each term into boolean should and scores are only computed as the boost using the top N scoring terms. Replace N with an integer value.

  • top_terms_N - first translates each term into boolean should and keeps the scores as computed by the query. Only the top N scoring terms are used. Replace N with an integer value.

Default is constant_score.

This is an advanced option, use with care.

Note: The deprecated multi term rewrite parameters constant_score_auto, constant_score_filter (synonyms for constant_score) have been removed in elasticsearch 6.0.

fuzzyRewrite(method: string): MatchQuery
Parameters
method (string) The rewrite method as a string.
Returns
MatchQuery: returns this so that calls can be chained.
Throws
  • Error: If the given fuzzy_rewrite method is not valid.
▸ fuzzyTranspositions(enable)
src/queries/full-text-queries/match-query.js

Fuzzy transpositions (ab → ba) are allowed by default but can be disabled by setting fuzzy_transpositions to false.

fuzzyTranspositions(enable: boolean): MatchQuery
Parameters
enable (boolean)
Returns
MatchQuery: returns this so that calls can be chained.
▸ zeroTermsQuery(behavior)
src/queries/full-text-queries/match-query.js

If the analyzer used removes all tokens in a query like a stop filter does, the default behavior is to match no documents at all. In order to change that the zero_terms_query option can be used, which accepts none (default) and all which corresponds to a match_all query.

zeroTermsQuery(behavior: string): MatchQuery
Parameters
behavior (string) A no match action, all or none . Default is none .
Returns
MatchQuery: returns this so that calls can be chained.
Example
const qry = esb.matchQuery('message', 'to be or not to be')
    .operator('and')
    .zeroTermsQuery('all');
▸ cutoffFrequency(frequency)
src/queries/full-text-queries/match-query.js

Allows specifying an absolute or relative document frequency where high frequency terms are moved into an optional subquery and are only scored if one of the low frequency (below the cutoff) terms in the case of an or operator or all of the low frequency terms in the case of an and operator match.

cutoffFrequency(frequency: number): MatchQuery
Parameters
frequency (number) It can either be relative to the total number of documents if in the range [0..1) or absolute if greater or equal to 1.0 .
Returns
MatchQuery: returns this so that calls can be chained.
Example
const qry = esb.matchQuery('message', 'to be or not to be')
    .cutoffFrequency(0.001);

MatchPhraseQueryBase

src/queries/full-text-queries/match-phrase-query-base.js

The MatchPhraseQueryBase provides support for common options used across various bucket match phrase query implementations.

NOTE: Instantiating this directly should not be required. However, if you wish to add a custom implementation for whatever reason, this class could be extended.

new MatchPhraseQueryBase(queryType: string, refUrl: string, field: string?, queryString: string?)

Extends MonoFieldQueryBase

Parameters
queryType (string)
refUrl (string)
field (string?) The document field to query against
queryString (string?) The query string
Instance Members
▸ minimumShouldMatch()
src/queries/full-text-queries/match-phrase-query-base.js
minimumShouldMatch()
Throws
  • Error: This method cannot be called on MatchPhraseQueryBase
▸ slop(slop)
src/queries/full-text-queries/match-phrase-query-base.js

Configures the slop(default is 0) for matching terms in any order. Transposed terms have a slop of 2.

slop(slop: number): MatchPhraseQueryBase
Parameters
slop (number) A positive integer value, defaults is 0.
Returns
MatchPhraseQueryBase: returns this so that calls can be chained.

MatchPhraseQuery

src/queries/full-text-queries/match-phrase-query.js

The match_phrase query analyzes the text and creates a phrase query out of the analyzed text.

Elasticsearch reference

new MatchPhraseQuery(field: string?, queryString: string?)

Extends MatchPhraseQueryBase

Parameters
field (string?) The document field to query against
queryString (string?) The query string
Example
const qry = esb.matchPhraseQuery('message', 'to be or not to be');

Elasticsearch reference

new MatchPhrasePrefixQuery(field: string?, queryString: string?)

Extends MatchPhraseQueryBase

Parameters
field (string?) The document field to query against
queryString (string?) The query string
Example
const qry = esb.matchPhrasePrefixQuery('message', 'quick brown f');
Instance Members
▸ maxExpansions(limit)
src/queries/full-text-queries/match-phrase-prefix-query.js

Control to how many prefixes the last term will be expanded.

maxExpansions(limit: number): MatchPhrasePrefixQuery
Parameters
limit (number) Defaults to 50.
Returns
MatchPhrasePrefixQuery: returns this so that calls can be chained.
Example
const qry = esb.matchPhrasePrefixQuery('message', 'quick brown f')
    .maxExpansions(10);

MultiMatchQuery

src/queries/full-text-queries/multi-match-query.js

A MultiMatchQuery query builds further on top of the MultiMatchQuery by allowing multiple fields to be specified. The idea here is to allow to more easily build a concise match type query over multiple fields instead of using a relatively more expressive query by using multiple match queries within a bool query.

Elasticsearch reference

new MultiMatchQuery(fields: (Array<string> | string)?, queryString: string?)

Extends FullTextQueryBase

Parameters
fields ((Array<string> | string)?) The fields to be queried
queryString (string?) The query string
Example
const qry = esb.multiMatchQuery(['subject', 'message'], 'this is a test');
Instance Members
▸ field(field)
src/queries/full-text-queries/multi-match-query.js

Appends given field to the list of fields to search against. Fields can be specified with wildcards. Individual fields can be boosted with the caret (^) notation. Example - "subject^3"

field(field: string): MultiMatchQuery
Parameters
field (string) One of the fields to be queried
Returns
MultiMatchQuery: returns this so that calls can be chained.
▸ fields(fields)
src/queries/full-text-queries/multi-match-query.js

Appends given fields to the list of fields to search against. Fields can be specified with wildcards. Individual fields can be boosted with the caret (^) notation.

fields(fields: Array<string>): MultiMatchQuery
Parameters
fields (Array<string>) The fields to be queried
Returns
MultiMatchQuery: returns this so that calls can be chained.
Example
// Boost individual fields with caret `^` notation
const qry = esb.multiMatchQuery(['subject^3', 'message'], 'this is a test');
// Specify fields with wildcards
const qry = esb.multiMatchQuery(['title', '*_name'], 'Will Smith');
▸ type(type)
src/queries/full-text-queries/multi-match-query.js

Sets the type of multi match query. Valid values are:

  • best_fields - (default) Finds documents which match any field, but uses the _score from the best field.

  • most_fields - Finds documents which match any field and combines the _score from each field.

  • cross_fields - Treats fields with the same analyzer as though they were one big field. Looks for each word in any field

  • phrase - Runs a match_phrase query on each field and combines the _score from each field.

  • phrase_prefix - Runs a match_phrase_prefix query on each field and combines the _score from each field.

  • bool_prefix - (added in v7.2) Creates a match_bool_prefix query on each field and combines the _score from each field.

type(type: string): MultiMatchQuery
Parameters
type (string) Can be one of best_fields , most_fields , cross_fields , phrase , phrase_prefix and bool_prefix . Default is best_fields .
Returns
MultiMatchQuery: returns this so that calls can be chained.
Example
// Find the single best matching field
const qry = esb.multiMatchQuery(['subject', 'message'], 'brown fox')
    .type('best_fields')
    .tieBreaker(0.3);
// Query multiple fields analyzed differently for the same text
const qry = esb.multiMatchQuery(
    ['title', 'title.original', 'title.shingles'],
    'quick brown fox'
).type('most_fields');
// Run a `match_phrase_prefix` query on multiple fields
const qry = esb.multiMatchQuery(
    ['subject', 'message'],
    'quick brown f'
).type('phrase_prefix');
// All terms must be present in at least one field for document to match
const qry = esb.multiMatchQuery(['first_name', 'last_name'], 'Will Smith')
    .type('cross_fields')
    .operator('and');
▸ tieBreaker(factor)
src/queries/full-text-queries/multi-match-query.js

The tie breaker value. The tie breaker capability allows results that include the same term in multiple fields to be judged better than results that include this term in only the best of those multiple fields, without confusing this with the better case of two different terms in the multiple fields. Default: 0.0.

tieBreaker(factor: number): MultiMatchQuery
Parameters
factor (number)
Returns
MultiMatchQuery: returns this so that calls can be chained.
▸ operator(operator)
src/queries/full-text-queries/multi-match-query.js

The operator to be used in the boolean query which is constructed by analyzing the text provided. The operator flag can be set to or or and to control the boolean clauses (defaults to or).

operator(operator: string): MultiMatchQuery
Parameters
operator (string) Can be and / or . Default is or .
Returns
MultiMatchQuery: returns this so that calls can be chained.
▸ lenient(enable)
src/queries/full-text-queries/multi-match-query.js

Sets the lenient parameter which allows to ignore exceptions caused by data-type mismatches such as trying to query a numeric field with a text query string when set to true.

lenient(enable: boolean): MultiMatchQuery
Parameters
enable (boolean) Defaules to false
Returns
MultiMatchQuery: returns this so that calls can be chained.
▸ slop(slop)
src/queries/full-text-queries/multi-match-query.js

Configures the slop(default is 0) for matching terms in any order. Transposed terms have a slop of 2.

slop(slop: number): MultiMatchQuery
Parameters
slop (number) A positive integer value, defaults is 0.
Returns
MultiMatchQuery: returns this so that calls can be chained.
▸ fuzziness(factor)
src/queries/full-text-queries/multi-match-query.js

Sets the fuzziness parameter which is interpreted as a Levenshtein Edit Distance — the number of one character changes that need to be made to one string to make it the same as another string.

The fuzziness parameter cannot be used with the phrase, phrase_prefix or cross_fields type.

fuzziness(factor: (number | string)): MultiMatchQuery
Parameters
factor ((number | string)) Can be specified either as a number, or the maximum number of edits, or as AUTO which generates an edit distance based on the length of the term.
Returns
MultiMatchQuery: returns this so that calls can be chained.
▸ prefixLength(len)
src/queries/full-text-queries/multi-match-query.js

Sets the prefix length for a fuzzy prefix MultiMatchQuery

prefixLength(len: number): MultiMatchQuery
Parameters
len (number)
Returns
MultiMatchQuery: returns this so that calls can be chained.
▸ maxExpansions(limit)
src/queries/full-text-queries/multi-match-query.js

Sets the max expansions for a fuzzy prefix MultiMatchQuery

maxExpansions(limit: number): MultiMatchQuery
Parameters
limit (number)
Returns
MultiMatchQuery: returns this so that calls can be chained.
▸ rewrite(method)
src/queries/full-text-queries/multi-match-query.js

Sets the rewrite method. Valid values are:

  • constant_score - tries to pick the best constant-score rewrite method based on term and document counts from the query. Synonyms - constant_score_auto, constant_score_filter

  • scoring_boolean - translates each term into boolean should and keeps the scores as computed by the query

  • constant_score_boolean - same as scoring_boolean, expect no scores are computed.

  • constant_score_filter - first creates a private Filter, by visiting each term in sequence and marking all docs for that term

  • top_terms_boost_N - first translates each term into boolean should and scores are only computed as the boost using the top N scoring terms. Replace N with an integer value.

  • top_terms_N - first translates each term into boolean should and keeps the scores as computed by the query. Only the top N scoring terms are used. Replace N with an integer value.

Default is constant_score.

This is an advanced option, use with care.

Note: The deprecated multi term rewrite parameters constant_score_auto, constant_score_filter (synonyms for constant_score) have been removed in elasticsearch 6.0.

rewrite(method: string): MultiMatchQuery
Parameters
method (string) The rewrite method as a string.
Returns
MultiMatchQuery: returns this so that calls can be chained.
Throws
  • Error: If the given rewrite method is not valid.
▸ fuzzyRewrite(method)
src/queries/full-text-queries/multi-match-query.js

Sets the fuzzy rewrite method. Valid values are:

  • constant_score - tries to pick the best constant-score rewrite method based on term and document counts from the query. Synonyms - constant_score_auto, constant_score_filter

  • scoring_boolean - translates each term into boolean should and keeps the scores as computed by the query

  • constant_score_boolean - same as scoring_boolean, expect no scores are computed.

  • constant_score_filter - first creates a private Filter, by visiting each term in sequence and marking all docs for that term

  • top_terms_boost_N - first translates each term into boolean should and scores are only computed as the boost using the top N scoring terms. Replace N with an integer value.

  • top_terms_N - first translates each term into boolean should and keeps the scores as computed by the query. Only the top N scoring terms are used. Replace N with an integer value.

Default is constant_score.

This is an advanced option, use with care.

Note: The deprecated multi term rewrite parameters constant_score_auto, constant_score_filter (synonyms for constant_score) have been removed in elasticsearch 6.0.

fuzzyRewrite(method: string): MultiMatchQuery
Parameters
method (string) The rewrite method as a string.
Returns
MultiMatchQuery: returns this so that calls can be chained.
Throws
  • Error: If the given fuzzy_rewrite method is not valid.
▸ zeroTermsQuery(behavior)
src/queries/full-text-queries/multi-match-query.js

If the analyzer used removes all tokens in a query like a stop filter does, the default behavior is to match no documents at all. In order to change that the zero_terms_query option can be used, which accepts none (default) and all which corresponds to a match_all query.

zeroTermsQuery(behavior: string): MultiMatchQuery
Parameters
behavior (string) A no match action, all or none . Default is none .
Returns
MultiMatchQuery: returns this so that calls can be chained.
▸ cutoffFrequency(frequency)
src/queries/full-text-queries/multi-match-query.js

Allows specifying an absolute or relative document frequency where high frequency terms are moved into an optional subquery and are only scored if one of the low frequency (below the cutoff) terms in the case of an or operator or all of the low frequency terms in the case of an and operator match.

cutoffFrequency(frequency: number): MultiMatchQuery
Parameters
frequency (number) It can either be relative to the total number of documents if in the range [0..1) or absolute if greater or equal to 1.0 .
Returns
MultiMatchQuery: returns this so that calls can be chained.

CommonTermsQuery

src/queries/full-text-queries/common-terms-query.js

The common terms query is a modern alternative to stopwords which improves the precision and recall of search results (by taking stopwords into account), without sacrificing performance.

Elasticsearch reference

new CommonTermsQuery(field: string?, queryString: string?)

Extends MonoFieldQueryBase

Parameters
field (string?) The document field to query against
queryString (string?) The query string
Example
const qry = esb.commonTermsQuery('body','this is bonsai cool')
    .cutoffFrequency(0.001);
Instance Members
▸ cutoffFrequency(frequency)
src/queries/full-text-queries/common-terms-query.js

Allows specifying an absolute or relative document frequency where high frequency terms are moved into an optional subquery and are only scored if one of the low frequency (below the cutoff) terms in the case of an or operator or all of the low frequency terms in the case of an and operator match.

cutoffFrequency(frequency: number): CommonTermsQuery
Parameters
frequency (number) It can either be relative to the total number of documents if in the range [0..1) or absolute if greater or equal to 1.0 .
Returns
CommonTermsQuery: returns this so that calls can be chained.
▸ lowFreqOperator(operator)
src/queries/full-text-queries/common-terms-query.js

The operator to be used on low frequency terms in the boolean query which is constructed by analyzing the text provided. The operator flag can be set to or or and to control the boolean clauses (defaults to or).

lowFreqOperator(operator: string): CommonTermsQuery
Parameters
operator (string) Can be and / or . Default is or .
Returns
CommonTermsQuery: returns this so that calls can be chained.
Example
const qry = esb.commonTermsQuery('body', 'nelly the elephant as a cartoon')
    .lowFreqOperator('and')
    .cutoffFrequency(0.001);
▸ highFreqOperator(operator)
src/queries/full-text-queries/common-terms-query.js

The operator to be used on high frequency terms in the boolean query which is constructed by analyzing the text provided. The operator flag can be set to or or and to control the boolean clauses (defaults to or).

highFreqOperator(operator: string): CommonTermsQuery
Parameters
operator (string) Can be and / or . Default is or .
Returns
CommonTermsQuery: returns this so that calls can be chained.
▸ lowFreq(lowFreqMinMatch)
src/queries/full-text-queries/common-terms-query.js

Sets the value controlling how many "should" clauses in the resulting boolean query should match for low frequency terms. It can be an absolute value (2), a percentage (30%) or a combination of both.

lowFreq(lowFreqMinMatch: (string | number)): CommonTermsQuery
Parameters
lowFreqMinMatch ((string | number))
Returns
CommonTermsQuery: returns this so that calls can be chained.
Example
const qry = esb.commonTermsQuery('body', 'nelly the elephant as a cartoon')
    .lowFreq(2)
    .highFreq(3)
    .cutoffFrequency(0.001);
▸ highFreq(highFreqMinMatch)
src/queries/full-text-queries/common-terms-query.js

Sets the value controlling how many "should" clauses in the resulting boolean query should match for high frequency terms. It can be an absolute value (2), a percentage (30%) or a combination of both.

highFreq(highFreqMinMatch: (string | number)): CommonTermsQuery
Parameters
highFreqMinMatch ((string | number))
Returns
CommonTermsQuery: returns this so that calls can be chained.
Example
const qry = esb.commonTermsQuery('body', 'nelly the elephant as a cartoon')
    .lowFreq(2)
    .highFreq(3)
    .cutoffFrequency(0.001);
▸ disableCoord(enable)
src/queries/full-text-queries/common-terms-query.js

Enables or disables similarity coordinate scoring of documents commoning the CommonTermsQuery. Default: false.

NOTE: This has been removed in elasticsearch 6.0. If provided, it will be ignored and a deprecation warning will be issued.

disableCoord(enable: boolean): CommonTermsQuery
Parameters
enable (boolean)
Returns
CommonTermsQuery: returns this so that calls can be chained.

QueryStringQueryBase

src/queries/full-text-queries/query-string-query-base.js

The QueryStringQueryBase provides support for common options used across full text query implementations QueryStringQuery and SimpleQueryStringQuery. A query that uses a query parser in order to parse its content.

NOTE: Instantiating this directly should not be required. However, if you wish to add a custom implementation for whatever reason, this class could be extended.

Elasticsearch reference

new QueryStringQueryBase(queryType: string, refUrl: string, queryString: string?)

Extends FullTextQueryBase

Parameters
queryType (string)
refUrl (string)
queryString (string?) The actual query to be parsed.
Instance Members
▸ field(field)
src/queries/full-text-queries/query-string-query-base.js

Appends given field to the list of fields to search against. Fields can be specified with wildcards.

Individual fields can be boosted with the caret (^) notation. Example - "subject^3"

field(field: string): QueryStringQueryBase
Parameters
field (string) One of the fields to be queried
Returns
QueryStringQueryBase: returns this so that calls can be chained.
Example
const qry = esb.queryStringQuery('this AND that OR thus')
    .field('city.*')
    .useDisMax(true);
const qry = esb.simpleQueryStringQuery('foo bar -baz').field('content');
▸ fields(fields)
src/queries/full-text-queries/query-string-query-base.js

Appends given fields to the list of fields to search against. Fields can be specified with wildcards.

Individual fields can be boosted with the caret (^) notation. Example - [ "subject^3", "message" ]

fields(fields: Array<string>): QueryStringQueryBase
Parameters
fields (Array<string>) The fields to be queried
Returns
QueryStringQueryBase: returns this so that calls can be chained.
Example
const qry = esb.queryStringQuery('this AND that')
    .fields(['content', 'name'])
const qry = esb.simpleQueryStringQuery('foo bar baz')
    .fields(['content', 'name.*^5']);
▸ defaultOperator(operator)
src/queries/full-text-queries/query-string-query-base.js

The default operator used if no explicit operator is specified. For example, with a default operator of OR, the query capital of Hungary is translated to capital OR of OR Hungary, and with default operator of AND, the same query is translated to capital AND of AND Hungary. The default value is OR.

defaultOperator(operator: string): QueryStringQueryBase
Parameters
operator (string) Can be AND / OR . Default is OR .
Returns
QueryStringQueryBase: returns this so that calls can be chained.
▸ analyzeWildcard(enable)
src/queries/full-text-queries/query-string-query-base.js

By default, wildcards terms in a query string are not analyzed. By setting this value to true, a best effort will be made to analyze those as well.

analyzeWildcard(enable: boolean): QueryStringQueryBase
Parameters
enable (boolean)
Returns
QueryStringQueryBase: returns this so that calls can be chained.
▸ lenient(enable)
src/queries/full-text-queries/query-string-query-base.js

Sets the lenient parameter which allows to ignore exceptions caused by data-type mismatches such as trying to query a numeric field with a text query string when set to true.

lenient(enable: boolean): QueryStringQueryBase
Parameters
enable (boolean) Defaules to false
Returns
QueryStringQueryBase: returns this so that calls can be chained.
▸ quoteFieldSuffix(suffix)
src/queries/full-text-queries/query-string-query-base.js

A suffix to append to fields for quoted parts of the query string. This allows to use a field that has a different analysis chain for exact matching.

quoteFieldSuffix(suffix: string): QueryStringQueryBase
Parameters
suffix (string)
Returns
QueryStringQueryBase: returns this so that calls can be chained.
▸ allFields(enable)
src/queries/full-text-queries/query-string-query-base.js

Perform the query on all fields detected in the mapping that can be queried. Will be used by default when the _all field is disabled and no default_field is specified (either in the index settings or in the request body) and no fields are specified.

allFields(enable: boolean): QueryStringQueryBase
Parameters
enable (boolean)
Returns
QueryStringQueryBase: returns this so that calls can be chained.

QueryStringQuery

src/queries/full-text-queries/query-string-query.js

A query that uses a query parser in order to parse its content.

Elasticsearch reference

new QueryStringQuery(queryString: string?)

Extends QueryStringQueryBase

Parameters
queryString (string?) The actual query to be parsed.
Example
const qry = esb.queryStringQuery('this AND that OR thus')
    .defaultField('content');
Instance Members
▸ defaultField(field)
src/queries/full-text-queries/query-string-query.js

The default field for query terms if no prefix field is specified. Defaults to the index.query.default_field index settings, which in turn defaults to _all.

defaultField(field: string): QueryStringQuery
Parameters
field (string)
Returns
QueryStringQuery: returns this so that calls can be chained.
▸ allowLeadingWildcard(enable)
src/queries/full-text-queries/query-string-query.js

When set, * or ? are allowed as the first character. Defaults to true.

allowLeadingWildcard(enable: boolean): QueryStringQuery
Parameters
enable (boolean)
Returns
QueryStringQuery: returns this so that calls can be chained.
▸ enablePositionIncrements(enable)
src/queries/full-text-queries/query-string-query.js

Set to true to enable position increments in result queries. Defaults to true.

enablePositionIncrements(enable: boolean): QueryStringQuery
Parameters
enable (boolean)
Returns
QueryStringQuery: returns this so that calls can be chained.
▸ fuzzyMaxExpansions(limit)
src/queries/full-text-queries/query-string-query.js

Controls the number of terms fuzzy queries will expand to. Defaults to 50.

fuzzyMaxExpansions(limit: number): QueryStringQuery
Parameters
limit (number)
Returns
QueryStringQuery: returns this so that calls can be chained.
▸ fuzziness(factor)
src/queries/full-text-queries/query-string-query.js

Sets the fuzziness parameter which is interpreted as a Levenshtein Edit Distance — the number of one character changes that need to be made to one string to make it the same as another string. Defaults to AUTO.

fuzziness(factor: (number | string)): QueryStringQuery
Parameters
factor ((number | string)) Can be specified either as a number, or the maximum number of edits, or as AUTO which generates an edit distance based on the length of the term. Defaults to AUTO .
Returns
QueryStringQuery: returns this so that calls can be chained.
▸ fuzzyPrefixLength(len)
src/queries/full-text-queries/query-string-query.js

Set the prefix length for fuzzy queries. Default is 0.

fuzzyPrefixLength(len: number): QueryStringQuery
Parameters
len (number)
Returns
QueryStringQuery: returns this so that calls can be chained.
▸ rewrite(method)
src/queries/full-text-queries/query-string-query.js

Sets the rewrite method. Valid values are:

  • constant_score - tries to pick the best constant-score rewrite method based on term and document counts from the query. Synonyms - constant_score_auto, constant_score_filter

  • scoring_boolean - translates each term into boolean should and keeps the scores as computed by the query

  • constant_score_boolean - same as scoring_boolean, expect no scores are computed.

  • constant_score_filter - first creates a private Filter, by visiting each term in sequence and marking all docs for that term

  • top_terms_boost_N - first translates each term into boolean should and scores are only computed as the boost using the top N scoring terms. Replace N with an integer value.

  • top_terms_N - first translates each term into boolean should and keeps the scores as computed by the query. Only the top N scoring terms are used. Replace N with an integer value.

Default is constant_score.

This is an advanced option, use with care.

Note: The deprecated multi term rewrite parameters constant_score_auto, constant_score_filter (synonyms for constant_score) have been removed in elasticsearch 6.0.

rewrite(method: string): QueryStringQuery
Parameters
method (string) The rewrite method as a string.
Returns
QueryStringQuery: returns this so that calls can be chained.
Throws
  • Error: If the given rewrite method is not valid.
▸ fuzzyRewrite(method)
src/queries/full-text-queries/query-string-query.js

Sets the fuzzy rewrite method. Valid values are:

  • constant_score - tries to pick the best constant-score rewrite method based on term and document counts from the query. Synonyms - constant_score_auto, constant_score_filter

  • scoring_boolean - translates each term into boolean should and keeps the scores as computed by the query

  • constant_score_boolean - same as scoring_boolean, expect no scores are computed.

  • constant_score_filter - first creates a private Filter, by visiting each term in sequence and marking all docs for that term

  • top_terms_boost_N - first translates each term into boolean should and scores are only computed as the boost using the top N scoring terms. Replace N with an integer value.

  • top_terms_N - first translates each term into boolean should and keeps the scores as computed by the query. Only the top N scoring terms are used. Replace N with an integer value.

Default is constant_score.

This is an advanced option, use with care.

Note: The deprecated multi term rewrite parameters constant_score_auto, constant_score_filter (synonyms for constant_score) have been removed in elasticsearch 6.0.

fuzzyRewrite(method: string): QueryStringQuery
Parameters
method (string) The rewrite method as a string.
Returns
QueryStringQuery: returns this so that calls can be chained.
Throws
  • Error: If the given fuzzy_rewrite method is not valid.
▸ phraseSlop(slop)
src/queries/full-text-queries/query-string-query.js

Sets the default slop for phrases. If zero, then exact phrase matches are required. Default value is 0.

phraseSlop(slop: number): QueryStringQuery
Parameters
slop (number) A positive integer value, defaults is 0.
Returns
QueryStringQuery: returns this so that calls can be chained.
▸ autoGeneratePhraseQueries(enable)
src/queries/full-text-queries/query-string-query.js

Auto generate phrase queries. Defaults to false.

Note: This parameter has been removed in elasticsearch 6.0. If provided, it will be ignored and issue a deprecation warning.

autoGeneratePhraseQueries(enable: boolean): QueryStringQuery
Parameters
enable (boolean)
Returns
QueryStringQuery: returns this so that calls can be chained.
▸ maxDeterminizedStates(limit)
src/queries/full-text-queries/query-string-query.js

Limit on how many automaton states regexp queries are allowed to create. This protects against too-difficult (e.g. exponentially hard) regexps. Defaults to 10000.

maxDeterminizedStates(limit: number): QueryStringQuery
Parameters
limit (number)
Returns
QueryStringQuery: returns this so that calls can be chained.
▸ timeZone(zone)
src/queries/full-text-queries/query-string-query.js

Time Zone to be applied to any range query related to dates.

timeZone(zone: string): QueryStringQuery
Parameters
zone (string)
Returns
QueryStringQuery: returns this so that calls can be chained.
▸ splitOnWhitespace(enable)
src/queries/full-text-queries/query-string-query.js

Whether query text should be split on whitespace prior to analysis. Instead the queryparser would parse around only real operators. Default is false. It is not allowed to set this option to false if auto_generate_phrase_queries is already set to true.

Note: This parameter has been removed in elasticsearch 6.0. If provided, it will be ignored and issue a deprecation warning. The query_string query now splits on operator only.

splitOnWhitespace(enable: string): QueryStringQuery
Parameters
enable (string)
Returns
QueryStringQuery: returns this so that calls can be chained.
▸ useDisMax(enable)
src/queries/full-text-queries/query-string-query.js

Should the queries be combined using dis_max (set it to true), or a bool query (set it to false). Defaults to true.

Note: This parameter has been removed in elasticsearch 6.0. If provided, it will be ignored and issue a deprecation warning. The tie_breaker parameter must be used instead.

useDisMax(enable: boolean): QueryStringQuery
Parameters
enable (boolean)
Returns
QueryStringQuery: returns this so that calls can be chained.
Example
const qry = esb.queryStringQuery('this AND that OR thus')
    .fields(['content', 'name^5'])
    .useDisMax(true);
▸ tieBreaker(factor)
src/queries/full-text-queries/query-string-query.js

When using dis_max, the disjunction max tie breaker. Defaults to 0.

tieBreaker(factor: number): QueryStringQuery
Parameters
factor (number)
Returns
QueryStringQuery: returns this so that calls can be chained.
▸ quoteAnalyzer(analyzer)
src/queries/full-text-queries/query-string-query.js

Sets the quote analyzer name used to analyze the query when in quoted text.

quoteAnalyzer(analyzer: string): QueryStringQuery
Parameters
analyzer (string) A valid analyzer name.
Returns
QueryStringQuery: returns this so that calls can be chained.
▸ escape(enable)
src/queries/full-text-queries/query-string-query.js

If they query string should be escaped or not.

escape(enable: boolean): QueryStringQuery
Parameters
enable (boolean)
Returns
QueryStringQuery: returns this so that calls can be chained.

SimpleQueryStringQuery

src/queries/full-text-queries/simple-query-string-query.js

A query that uses the SimpleQueryParser to parse its context. Unlike the regular query_string query, the simple_query_string query will never throw an exception, and discards invalid parts of the query.

Elasticsearch reference

new SimpleQueryStringQuery(queryString: string?)

Extends QueryStringQueryBase

Parameters
queryString (string?) The query string
Example
const qry = esb.simpleQueryStringQuery(
    '"fried eggs" +(eggplant | potato) -frittata'
)
    .analyzer('snowball')
    .fields(['body^5', '_all'])
    .defaultOperator('and');
Instance Members
▸ flags(flags)
src/queries/full-text-queries/simple-query-string-query.js

simple_query_string support multiple flags to specify which parsing features should be enabled. It is specified as a |-delimited string.

flags(flags: string): SimpleQueryStringQuery
Parameters
flags (string) | delimited string. The available flags are: ALL , NONE , AND , OR , NOT , PREFIX , PHRASE , PRECEDENCE , ESCAPE , WHITESPACE , FUZZY , NEAR , and SLOP .
Returns
SimpleQueryStringQuery: returns this so that calls can be chained.
Example
const qry = esb.simpleQueryStringQuery('foo | bar + baz*')
    .flags('OR|AND|PREFIX');

Term Level Queries

Term Level Queries

ValueTermQueryBase

src/queries/term-level-queries/value-term-query-base.js

The ValueTermQueryBase provides support for common options used across various term level query implementations.

new ValueTermQueryBase(queryType: string, field: string?, value: string?)

Extends Query

Parameters
queryType (string)
field (string?) The document field to query against
value (string?) The query string
Instance Members
▸ field(field)
src/queries/term-level-queries/value-term-query-base.js

Sets the field to search on.

field(field: string): ValueTermQueryBase
Parameters
field (string)
Returns
ValueTermQueryBase: returns this so that calls can be chained.
▸ value(queryVal)
src/queries/term-level-queries/value-term-query-base.js

Sets the query string.

value(queryVal: (string | number | boolean)): ValueTermQueryBase
Parameters
queryVal ((string | number | boolean))
Returns
ValueTermQueryBase: returns this so that calls can be chained.
▸ toJSON()
src/queries/term-level-queries/value-term-query-base.js

Override default toJSON to return DSL representation of the term level query class instance.

toJSON(): Object
Returns
Object: returns an Object which maps to the elasticsearch query DSL
▸ caseInsensitive(value)
src/queries/term-level-queries/value-term-query-base.js

Allows ASCII case insensitive matching of the value with the indexed field values when set to true.

NOTE: Only available in Elasticsearch v7.10.0+

caseInsensitive(value: boolean): ValueTermQueryBase
Parameters
value (boolean = true)
Returns
ValueTermQueryBase: returns this so that calls can be chained.

TermQuery

src/queries/term-level-queries/term-query.js

The term query finds documents that contain the exact term specified in the inverted index.

Elasticsearch reference

new TermQuery(field: string?, queryVal: (string | number | boolean)?)

Extends ValueTermQueryBase

Parameters
field (string?)
queryVal ((string | number | boolean)?)
Example
const termQry = esb.termQuery('user', 'Kimchy');

TermsQuery

src/queries/term-level-queries/terms-query.js

Filters documents that have fields that match any of the provided terms (not analyzed).

Elasticsearch reference

new TermsQuery(field: string?, values: (Array | string | number | boolean)?)

Extends Query

Parameters
field (string?)
values ((Array | string | number | boolean)?)
Example
const qry = esb.constantScoreQuery(
    esb.termsQuery('user', ['kimchy', 'elasticsearch'])
);
const qry = esb.termsQuery('user')
    .index('users')
    .type('user')
    .id(2)
    .path('followers');
Instance Members
▸ field(field)
src/queries/term-level-queries/terms-query.js

Sets the field to search on.

field(field: string): TermsQuery
Parameters
field (string)
Returns
TermsQuery: returns this so that calls can be chained.
▸ value(value)
src/queries/term-level-queries/terms-query.js

Append given value to list of values to run Terms Query with.

value(value: (string | number | boolean)): TermsQuery
Parameters
value ((string | number | boolean))
Returns
TermsQuery: returns this so that calls can be chained
▸ values(values)
src/queries/term-level-queries/terms-query.js

Specifies the values to run query for.

values(values: Array<(string | number | boolean)>): TermsQuery
Parameters
values (Array<(string | number | boolean)>) Values to run query for.
Returns
TermsQuery: returns this so that calls can be chained
Throws
  • TypeError: If values is not an instance of Array
▸ termsLookup(lookupOpts)
src/queries/term-level-queries/terms-query.js

Convenience method for setting term lookup options. Valid options are index, type, id, pathand routing

termsLookup(lookupOpts: Object): TermsQuery
Parameters
lookupOpts (Object) An object with any of the keys index , type , id , path and routing .
Returns
TermsQuery: returns this so that calls can be chained
▸ index(idx)
src/queries/term-level-queries/terms-query.js

The index to fetch the term values from. Defaults to the current index.

Note: The index parameter in the terms filter, used to look up terms in a dedicated index is mandatory in elasticsearch 6.0. Previously, the index defaulted to the index the query was executed on. In 6.0, this index must be explicitly set in the request.

index(idx: string): TermsQuery
Parameters
idx (string) The index to fetch the term values from. Defaults to the current index.
Returns
TermsQuery: returns this so that calls can be chained
▸ type(type)
src/queries/term-level-queries/terms-query.js

The type to fetch the term values from.

type(type: string): TermsQuery
Parameters
type (string)
Returns
TermsQuery: returns this so that calls can be chained

src/queries/term-level-queries/terms-query.js

The id of the document to fetch the term values from.

id(id: string): TermsQuery
Parameters
id (string)
Returns
TermsQuery: returns this so that calls can be chained
▸ path(path)
src/queries/term-level-queries/terms-query.js

The field specified as path to fetch the actual values for the terms filter.

path(path: string): TermsQuery
Parameters
path (string)
Returns
TermsQuery: returns this so that calls can be chained
▸ routing(routing)
src/queries/term-level-queries/terms-query.js

A custom routing value to be used when retrieving the external terms doc.

routing(routing: string): TermsQuery
Parameters
routing (string)
Returns
TermsQuery: returns this so that calls can be chained
▸ toJSON()
src/queries/term-level-queries/terms-query.js

Override default toJSON to return DSL representation of the terms query class instance.

toJSON(): Object
Returns
Object: returns an Object which maps to the elasticsearch query DSL

TermsSetQuery

src/queries/term-level-queries/terms-set-query.js

Returns any documents that match with at least one or more of the provided terms. The terms are not analyzed and thus must match exactly. The number of terms that must match varies per document and is either controlled by a minimum should match field or computed per document in a minimum should match script.

Elasticsearch reference

NOTE: This query was added in elasticsearch v6.1.

new TermsSetQuery(field: string?, terms: (Array<(string | number | boolean)> | string | number)?)

Extends Query

Parameters
field (string?)
terms ((Array<(string | number | boolean)> | string | number)?)
Example
const qry = esb.termsSetQuery('codes', ['abc', 'def', 'ghi'])
    .minimumShouldMatchField('required_matches')
Instance Members
▸ field(field)
src/queries/term-level-queries/terms-set-query.js

Sets the field to search on.

field(field: string): TermsSetQuery
Parameters
field (string)
Returns
TermsSetQuery: returns this so that calls can be chained.
▸ term(term)
src/queries/term-level-queries/terms-set-query.js

Append given term to set of terms to run Terms Set Query with.

term(term: (string | number | boolean)): TermsSetQuery
Parameters
term ((string | number | boolean))
Returns
TermsSetQuery: returns this so that calls can be chained
▸ terms(terms)
src/queries/term-level-queries/terms-set-query.js

Specifies the terms to run query for.

terms(terms: Array<(string | number | boolean)>): TermsSetQuery
Parameters
terms (Array<(string | number | boolean)>) Terms set to run query for.
Returns
TermsSetQuery: returns this so that calls can be chained
Throws
  • TypeError: If terms is not an instance of Array
▸ minimumShouldMatchField(fieldName)
src/queries/term-level-queries/terms-set-query.js

Controls the number of terms that must match per document.

minimumShouldMatchField(fieldName: string): TermsSetQuery
Parameters
fieldName (string)
Returns
TermsSetQuery: returns this so that calls can be chained
▸ minimumShouldMatchScript(script)
src/queries/term-level-queries/terms-set-query.js

Sets the script for query. It controls how many terms are required to match in a more dynamic way.

The params.num_terms parameter is available in the script to indicate the number of terms that have been specified.

minimumShouldMatchScript(script: (Script | string | Object)): ScriptQuery
Parameters
script ((Script | string | Object))
Returns
ScriptQuery: returns this so that calls can be chained.
Example
const qry = esb.termsSetQuery('codes', ['abc', 'def', 'ghi'])
    .minimumShouldMatchScript({
        source: "Math.min(params.num_terms, doc['required_matches'].value)"
    })
▸ toJSON()
src/queries/term-level-queries/terms-set-query.js

Override default toJSON to return DSL representation of the term level query class instance.

toJSON(): Object
Returns
Object: returns an Object which maps to the elasticsearch query DSL

MultiTermQueryBase

src/queries/term-level-queries/multi-term-query-base.js

Interface-like class used to group and identify various implementations of multi term queries:

  • Wildcard Query
  • Fuzzy Query
  • Prefix Query
  • Range Query
  • Regexp Query

NOTE: Instantiating this directly should not be required. However, if you wish to add a custom implementation for whatever reason, this class could be extended.

new MultiTermQueryBase()

Extends ValueTermQueryBase

RangeQuery

src/queries/term-level-queries/range-query.js

Matches documents with fields that have terms within a certain range.

Elasticsearch reference

new RangeQuery(field: string?)

Extends MultiTermQueryBase

Parameters
field (string?)
Example
const qry = esb.rangeQuery('age')
    .gte(10)
    .lte(20)
    .boost(2.0);
const qry = esb.rangeQuery('date').gte('now-1d/d').lt('now/d');
Instance Members
▸ value()
src/queries/term-level-queries/range-query.js
value()
Throws
  • Error: This method cannot be called on RangeQuery
▸ gte(val)
src/queries/term-level-queries/range-query.js

Greater-than or equal to

gte(val: (string | number)): RangeQuery
Parameters
val ((string | number))
Returns
RangeQuery: returns this so that calls can be chained.

Parameters
val ((string | number))
Returns
RangeQuery: returns this so that calls can be chained.

Greater-than

Parameters

Returns
RangeQuery: returns this so that calls can be chained.
