Bucket Aggregations

Bucket Aggregations

BucketAggregationBase

src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/bucket-aggregation-base.js

The BucketAggregationBase provides support for common options used across various bucket Aggregation implementations.

NOTE: Instantiating this directly should not be required. However, if you wish to add a custom implementation for whatever reason, this class could be extended.

new BucketAggregationBase(name: string, aggType: string, field: string?)

Extends Aggregation

Parameters
name (string) a valid aggregation name
aggType (string) type of aggregation
field (string?) The field to aggregate on
Instance Members
▸ field(field)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/bucket-aggregation-base.js

Sets field to run aggregation on.

field(field: string): BucketAggregationBase
Parameters
field (string) a valid field name
Returns
BucketAggregationBase: returns this so that calls can be chained
▸ script(script)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/bucket-aggregation-base.js

Sets script parameter for aggregation.

script(script: Script): BucketAggregationBase
Parameters
script (Script)
Returns
BucketAggregationBase: returns this so that calls can be chained
Throws
  • TypeError: If script is not an instance of Script
Example
// Generating the terms using a script
const agg = esb.termsAggregation('genres').script(
    esb.script('file', 'my_script').params({ field: 'genre' })
);
// Value script
const agg = esb.termsAggregation('genres', 'genre').script(
    esb.script('inline', "'Genre: ' +_value").lang('painless')
);

AdjacencyMatrixAggregation

src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/adjacency-matrix-aggregation.js

A bucket aggregation returning a form of adjacency matrix. The request provides a collection of named filter expressions, similar to the filters aggregation request. Each bucket in the response represents a non-empty cell in the matrix of intersecting filters.

Elasticsearch reference

new AdjacencyMatrixAggregation(name: string)

Extends BucketAggregationBase

Parameters
name (string) The name which will be used to refer to this aggregation.
Example
const agg = esb.adjacencyMatrixAggregation('interactions').filters({
    grpA: esb.termsQuery('accounts', ['hillary', 'sidney']),
    grpB: esb.termsQuery('accounts', ['donald', 'mitt']),
    grpC: esb.termsQuery('accounts', ['vladimir', 'nigel'])
});
Instance Members
▸ field()
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/adjacency-matrix-aggregation.js
field()
Throws
  • Error: This method cannot be called on AdjacencyMatrixAggregation
▸ script()
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/adjacency-matrix-aggregation.js
script()
Throws
  • Error: This method cannot be called on AdjacencyMatrixAggregation
▸ filter(filterName, filterQuery)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/adjacency-matrix-aggregation.js

Sets a named filter query.

filter(filterName: string, filterQuery: Query): AdjacencyMatrixAggregation
Parameters
filterName (string) Name for the filter.
filterQuery (Query) Query to filter on. Example - term query.
Returns
AdjacencyMatrixAggregation: returns this so that calls can be chained
Throws
  • TypeError: If filterQuery is not an instance of Query
▸ filters(filterQueries)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/adjacency-matrix-aggregation.js

Assigns filters to already added filters. Does not mix with anonymous filters. If anonymous filters are present, they will be overwritten.

filters(filterQueries: Object): AdjacencyMatrixAggregation
Parameters
filterQueries (Object) Object with multiple key value pairs where filter name is the key and filter query is the value.
Returns
AdjacencyMatrixAggregation: returns this so that calls can be chained
Throws
  • TypeError: If filterQueries is not an instance of object
▸ separator(sep)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/adjacency-matrix-aggregation.js

Sets the separator parameter to use a separator string other than the default of the ampersand.

separator(sep: string): AdjacencyMatrixAggregation
Parameters
sep (string) the string used to separate keys in intersections buckets e.g. & character for keyed filters A and B would return an intersection bucket named A&B
Returns
AdjacencyMatrixAggregation: returns this so that calls can be chained

AutoDateHistogramAggregation

src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/auto-date-histogram-aggregation.js

A multi-bucket aggregation similar to the Date histogram aggregation except instead of providing an interval to use as the width of each bucket, a target number of buckets is provided indicating the number of buckets needed and the interval of the buckets is automatically chosen to best achieve that target. The number of buckets returned will always be less than or equal to this target number.

Elasticsearch reference

new AutoDateHistogramAggregation(name: string, field: string, buckets: number)

Extends BucketAggregationBase

Parameters
name (string) The name which will be used to refer to this aggregation.
field (string) The field to aggregate on
buckets (number) Bucket count to generate histogram over.
Example
const agg = esb.autoDateHistogramAggregation('sales_over_time', 'date', 15);
Instance Members
▸ buckets(buckets)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/auto-date-histogram-aggregation.js

Sets the histogram bucket count. Buckets are generated based on this value.

buckets(buckets: number): AutoDateHistogramAggregation
Parameters
buckets (number) Bucket count to generate histogram over.
Returns
AutoDateHistogramAggregation: returns this so that calls can be chained
▸ minimumInterval(interval)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/auto-date-histogram-aggregation.js

The minimum_interval allows the caller to specify the minimum rounding interval that should be used. This can make the collection process more efficient, as the aggregation will not attempt to round at any interval lower than minimum_interval.

Accepted units: year, month, day, hour, minute, second

Elasticsearch reference

minimumInterval(interval: string): AutoDateHistogramAggregation
Parameters
interval (string) Minimum Rounding Interval Example: 'minute'
Returns
AutoDateHistogramAggregation: returns this so that calls can be chained
Example
const agg = esb.autoDateHistogramAggregation(
    'sales_over_time',
    'date',
    5
).minimumInterval('minute');
▸ format(fmt)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/auto-date-histogram-aggregation.js

Sets the format expression for key_as_string in response buckets. If no format is specified, then it will use the first format specified in the field mapping.

format(fmt: string): AutoDateHistogramAggregation
Parameters
fmt (string) Format mask to apply on aggregation response. Example: ####.00. For Date Histograms, supports expressive date format pattern
Returns
AutoDateHistogramAggregation: returns this so that calls can be chained
Example
const agg = esb.autoDateHistogramAggregation(
    'sales_over_time',
    'date',
    5
).format('yyyy-MM-dd');
▸ missing(value)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/auto-date-histogram-aggregation.js

Sets the missing parameter which defines how documents that are missing a value should be treated.

missing(value: string): AutoDateHistogramAggregation
Parameters
value (string)
Returns
AutoDateHistogramAggregation: returns this so that calls can be chained
Example
const agg = esb.autoDateHistogramAggregation('quantity', 'quantity', 10).missing(0);
▸ timeZone(tz)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/auto-date-histogram-aggregation.js

Date-times are stored in Elasticsearch in UTC. By default, all bucketing and rounding is also done in UTC. The time_zone parameter can be used to indicate that bucketing should use a different time zone. Sets the date time zone

timeZone(tz: string): AutoDateHistogramAggregation
Parameters
tz (string) Time zone. Time zones may either be specified as an ISO 8601 UTC offset (e.g. +01:00 or -08:00) or as a timezone id, an identifier used in the TZ database like America/Los_Angeles.
Returns
AutoDateHistogramAggregation: returns this so that calls can be chained
Example
const agg = esb.autoDateHistogramAggregation('by_day', 'date', 15).timeZone(
    '-01:00'
);

ChildrenAggregation

src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/children-aggregation.js

A special single bucket aggregation that enables aggregating from buckets on parent document types to buckets on child documents.

This aggregation relies on the _parent field in the mapping.

Elasticsearch reference

new ChildrenAggregation(name: string)

Extends BucketAggregationBase

Parameters
name (string) The name which will be used to refer to this aggregation.
Example
const reqBody = esb.requestBodySearch()
    .agg(
        esb.termsAggregation('top-tags', 'tags.keyword')
            .size(10)
            .agg(
                esb.childrenAggregation('to-answers')
                    .type('answer')
                    .agg(
                        esb.termsAggregation(
                            'top-names',
                            'owner.display_name.keyword'
                        ).size(10)
                    )
            )
    )
    .size(0);
Instance Members
▸ field()
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/children-aggregation.js
field()
Throws
  • Error: This method cannot be called on ChildrenAggregation
▸ script()
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/children-aggregation.js
script()
Throws
  • Error: This method cannot be called on ChildrenAggregation
▸ type(type)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/children-aggregation.js

Sets the child type/mapping for aggregation.

type(type: string): ChildrenAggregation
Parameters
type (string) The child type that the buckets in the parent space should be mapped to.
Returns
ChildrenAggregation: returns this so that calls can be chained

CompositeAggregation

src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/composite-aggregation.js

CompositeAggregation is a multi-bucket values source based aggregation that can be used to calculate unique composite values from source documents.

Unlike the other multi-bucket aggregation the composite aggregation can be used to paginate all buckets from a multi-level aggregation efficiently. This aggregation provides a way to stream all buckets of a specific aggregation similarly to what scroll does for documents.

Elasticsearch reference

new CompositeAggregation(name: string)

Extends Aggregation

Parameters
name (string) a valid aggregation name
Example
const reqBody = esb.requestBodySearch()
  .agg(
    esb.compositeAggregation('my_buckets')
      .sources(
        esb.CompositeAggregation.termsValuesSource('product', 'product')
      )
  )

NOTE: This query was added in elasticsearch v6.1.
Instance Members
▸ sources(sources)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/composite-aggregation.js

Specifies the Composite Aggregation values sources to use in the aggregation.

sources(sources: ...ValuesSourceBase): CompositeAggregation
Parameters
sources (...ValuesSourceBase)
Returns
CompositeAggregation: returns this so that calls can be chained
Throws
  • TypeError: If any of the rest parameters sources is not an instance of ValuesSourceBase
Example
const { CompositeAggregation } = esb;
const reqBody = esb.requestBodySearch()
  .agg(
    esb.compositeAggregation('my_buckets')
      .sources(
        CompositeAggregation.dateHistogramValuesSource(
          'date',
          'timestamp',
          '1d'
        ),
        CompositeAggregation.termsValuesSource('product', 'product')
      )
  );
▸ size(size)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/composite-aggregation.js

Defines how many composite buckets should be returned. Each composite bucket is considered as a single bucket so setting a size of 10 will return the first 10 composite buckets created from the values source. The response contains the values for each composite bucket in an array containing the values extracted from each value source.

size(size: number): CompositeAggregation
Parameters
size (number)
Returns
CompositeAggregation: returns this so that calls can be chained
▸ after(afterKey)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/composite-aggregation.js

The after parameter can be used to retrieve the composite buckets that are after the last composite buckets returned in a previous round.

after(afterKey: Object): CompositeAggregation
Parameters
afterKey (Object)
Returns
CompositeAggregation: returns this so that calls can be chained
Example
const { CompositeAggregation } = esb;
const reqBody = esb.requestBodySearch().agg(
  esb.compositeAggregation('my_buckets')
    .size(2)
    .sources(
      CompositeAggregation.dateHistogramValuesSource(
        'date',
        'timestamp',
        '1d'
      ).order('desc'),
      CompositeAggregation.termsValuesSource('product', 'product').order('asc')
    )
    .after({ date: 1494288000000, product: 'mad max' })
);

Values Source

The sources parameter controls the sources that should be used to build the composite buckets. There are three different types of values source:

  • Terms
  • Histogram
  • Date Histogram

Values Source

The sources parameter controls the sources that should be used to build the composite buckets. There are three different types of values source:

  • Terms
  • Histogram
  • Date Histogram

ValuesSourceBase

src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/composite-agg-values-sources/values-source-base.js

Base class implementation for all Composite Aggregation values sources.

NOTE: Instantiating this directly should not be required.

new ValuesSourceBase(valueSrcType: string, refUrl: string, name: string, field: string?)
Parameters
valueSrcType (string) Type of value source
refUrl (string) Elasticsearch reference URL
name (string)
field (string?) The field to aggregate on
Throws
  • Error: if name is empty
  • Error: if valueSrcType is empty
Instance Members
▸ field(field)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/composite-agg-values-sources/values-source-base.js

Field to use for this source.

field(field: string): ValuesSourceBase
Parameters
field (string) a valid field name
Returns
ValuesSourceBase: returns this so that calls can be chained
▸ script(script)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/composite-agg-values-sources/values-source-base.js

Script to use for this source.

script(script: (Script | Object | string)): ValuesSourceBase
Parameters
script ((Script | Object | string))
Returns
ValuesSourceBase: returns this so that calls can be chained
Throws
  • TypeError: If script is not an instance of Script
▸ valueType(valueType)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/composite-agg-values-sources/values-source-base.js

Specifies the type of values produced by this source, e.g. string or date.

valueType(valueType: string): ValuesSourceBase
Parameters
valueType (string)
Returns
ValuesSourceBase: returns this so that calls can be chained
▸ order(order)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/composite-agg-values-sources/values-source-base.js

Order specifies the order in the values produced by this source. It can be either asc or desc.

order(order: string): ValuesSourceBase
Parameters
order (string) The order option can have the following values. asc , desc to sort in ascending, descending order respectively.
Returns
ValuesSourceBase: returns this so that calls can be chained.
▸ missing(value)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/composite-agg-values-sources/values-source-base.js

Missing specifies the value to use when the source finds a missing value in a document.

Note: This option was deprecated in Elasticsearch v6. From 6.4 and later, use missing_bucket instead.

missing(value: (string | number)): ValuesSourceBase
Parameters
value ((string | number))
Returns
ValuesSourceBase: returns this so that calls can be chained
▸ missingBucket(value)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/composite-agg-values-sources/values-source-base.js

Specifies whether to include documents without a value for a given source in the response. Defaults to false (not included).

Note: This method is incompatible with elasticsearch 6.3 and older. Use it only with elasticsearch 6.4 and later.

missingBucket(value: boolean): ValuesSourceBase
Parameters
value (boolean)
Returns
ValuesSourceBase: returns this so that calls can be chained
▸ toJSON()
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/composite-agg-values-sources/values-source-base.js

Override default toJSON to return DSL representation for the Composite Aggregation values source.

toJSON(): Object
Returns
Object: returns an Object which maps to the elasticsearch query DSL

TermsValuesSource

src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/composite-agg-values-sources/terms-values-source.js

TermsValuesSource is a source for the CompositeAggregation that handles terms. It works very similar to a terms aggregation with a slightly different syntax.

Elasticsearch reference

new TermsValuesSource(name: string, field: string?)

Extends ValuesSourceBase

Parameters
name (string)
field (string?) The field to aggregate on
Example
const valueSrc = esb.CompositeAggregation.termsValuesSource('product').script({
  source: "doc['product'].value",
  lang: 'painless'
});

HistogramValuesSource

src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/composite-agg-values-sources/histogram-values-source.js

HistogramValuesSource is a source for the CompositeAggregation that handles histograms. It works very similar to a histogram aggregation with a slightly different syntax.

Elasticsearch reference

new HistogramValuesSource(name: string, field: string?, interval: number?)

Extends ValuesSourceBase

Parameters
name (string)
field (string?) The field to aggregate on
interval (number?) Interval to generate histogram over.
Example
const valueSrc = esb.CompositeAggregation.histogramValuesSource(
  'histo', // name
  'price', // field
  5 // interval
);
Instance Members
▸ interval(interval)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/composite-agg-values-sources/histogram-values-source.js

Sets the histogram interval. Buckets are generated based on this interval value.

interval(interval: number): HistogramValuesSource
Parameters
interval (number) Interval to generate histogram over.
Returns
HistogramValuesSource: returns this so that calls can be chained

DateHistogramValuesSource

src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/composite-agg-values-sources/date-histogram-values-source.js

DateHistogramValuesSource is a source for the CompositeAggregation that handles date histograms. It works very similar to a histogram aggregation with a slightly different syntax.

Elasticsearch reference

new DateHistogramValuesSource(name: string, field: string?, interval: (string | number)?)

Extends ValuesSourceBase

Parameters
name (string)
field (string?) The field to aggregate on
interval ((string | number)?) Interval to generate histogram over.
Example
const valueSrc = esb.CompositeAggregation.dateHistogramValuesSource(
  'date', // name
  'timestamp', // field
  '1d' // interval
);
Instance Members
▸ interval(interval)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/composite-agg-values-sources/date-histogram-values-source.js

Sets the histogram interval. Buckets are generated based on this interval value.

interval(interval: (string | number)): DateHistogramValuesSource
Parameters
interval ((string | number)) Interval to generate histogram over.
Returns
DateHistogramValuesSource: returns this so that calls can be chained
▸ calendarInterval(interval)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/composite-agg-values-sources/date-histogram-values-source.js

Calendar-aware intervals are configured with the calendarInterval parameter. The combined interval field for date histograms is deprecated from ES 7.2.

calendarInterval(interval: string): DateHistogramValuesSource
Parameters
interval (string) Interval to generate histogram over. You can specify calendar intervals using the unit name, such as month, or as a single unit quantity, such as 1M. For example, day and 1d are equivalent. Multiple quantities, such as 2d, are not supported.
Returns
DateHistogramValuesSource: returns this so that calls can be chained
Example
const agg = esb.dateHistogramValuesSource('by_month', 'date').calendarInterval(
    'month'
);
▸ fixedInterval(interval)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/composite-agg-values-sources/date-histogram-values-source.js

Fixed intervals are configured with the fixedInterval parameter. The combined interval field for date histograms is deprecated from ES 7.2.

fixedInterval(interval: string): DateHistogramValuesSource
Parameters
interval (string) Interval to generate histogram over. Intervals are a fixed number of SI units and never deviate, regardless of where they fall on the calendar. However, it means fixed intervals cannot express other units such as months, since the duration of a month is not a fixed quantity. The accepted units for fixed intervals are: millseconds (ms), seconds (s), minutes (m), hours (h) and days (d).
Returns
DateHistogramValuesSource: returns this so that calls can be chained
Example
const agg = esb.dateHistogramValuesSource('by_minute', 'date').calendarInterval(
    '60s'
);
▸ timeZone(tz)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/composite-agg-values-sources/date-histogram-values-source.js

Sets the date time zone

Date-times are stored in Elasticsearch in UTC. By default, all bucketing and rounding is also done in UTC. The time_zone parameter can be used to indicate that bucketing should use a different time zone.

timeZone(tz: string): DateHistogramValuesSource
Parameters
tz (string) Time zone. Time zones may either be specified as an ISO 8601 UTC offset (e.g. +01:00 or -08:00) or as a timezone id, an identifier used in the TZ database like America/Los_Angeles.
Returns
DateHistogramValuesSource: returns this so that calls can be chained
▸ format(fmt)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/composite-agg-values-sources/date-histogram-values-source.js

Sets the format expression for key_as_string in response buckets. If no format is specified, then it will use the first format specified in the field mapping.

format(fmt: string): DateHistogramValuesSource
Parameters
fmt (string) Format mask to apply on aggregation response. For Date Histograms, supports expressive date format pattern
Returns
DateHistogramValuesSource: returns this so that calls can be chained
Example
const valueSrc = esb.CompositeAggregation.valuesSource
  .dateHistogram('date', 'timestamp', '1d')
  .format('yyyy-MM-dd');

HistogramAggregationBase

src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/histogram-aggregation-base.js

The HistogramAggregationBase provides support for common options used across various histogram Aggregation implementations like Histogram Aggregation, Date Histogram aggregation.

NOTE: Instantiating this directly should not be required. However, if you wish to add a custom implementation for whatever reason, this class could be extended.

new HistogramAggregationBase(name: string, aggType: string, field: string?, interval: (string | number)?)

Extends BucketAggregationBase

Parameters
name (string) The name which will be used to refer to this aggregation.
aggType (string) Type of aggregation
field (string?) The field to aggregate on
interval ((string | number)?) Interval to generate histogram over.
Instance Members
▸ interval(interval)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/histogram-aggregation-base.js

Sets the histogram interval. Buckets are generated based on this interval value.

interval(interval: string): HistogramAggregationBase
Parameters
interval (string) Interval to generate histogram over. For date histograms, available expressions for interval: year, quarter, month, week, day, hour, minute, second
Returns
HistogramAggregationBase: returns this so that calls can be chained
▸ format(fmt)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/histogram-aggregation-base.js

Sets the format expression for key_as_string in response buckets. If no format is specified, then it will use the first format specified in the field mapping.

format(fmt: string): HistogramAggregationBase
Parameters
fmt (string) Format mask to apply on aggregation response. Example: ####.00. For Date Histograms, supports expressive date format pattern
Returns
HistogramAggregationBase: returns this so that calls can be chained
Example
const agg = esb.dateHistogramAggregation(
    'sales_over_time',
    'date',
    '1M'
).format('yyyy-MM-dd');
▸ offset(offset)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/histogram-aggregation-base.js

The offset parameter is used to change the start value of each bucket by the specified positive (+) or negative offset (-). Negative offset is not applicable on HistogramAggregation. In case of DateHistogramAggregation, duration can be a value such as 1h for an hour, or 1d for a day.

offset(offset: string): HistogramAggregationBase
Parameters
offset (string) Time or bucket key offset for bucketing.
Returns
HistogramAggregationBase: returns this so that calls can be chained
Example
const agg = esb.dateHistogramAggregation('by_day', 'date', 'day').offset('6h');
▸ order(key, direction)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/histogram-aggregation-base.js

Sets the ordering for buckets

order(key: string, direction: string): HistogramAggregationBase
Parameters
key (string)
direction (string = 'desc') asc or desc
Returns
HistogramAggregationBase: returns this so that calls can be chained
Example
const agg = esb.histogramAggregation('prices', 'price', 50)
    .order('_count', 'desc');
const agg = esb.histogramAggregation('prices', 'price', 50)
    .order('promoted_products>rating_stats.avg', 'desc')
    .agg(
        esb.filterAggregation('promoted_products')
            .filter(esb.termQuery('promoted', 'true'))
            .agg(esb.statsAggregation('rating_stats', 'rating'))
    );
▸ minDocCount(minDocCnt)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/histogram-aggregation-base.js

Sets the minimum number of matching documents in range to return the bucket.

minDocCount(minDocCnt: number): HistogramAggregationBase
Parameters
minDocCnt (number) Integer value for minimum number of documents required to return bucket in response
Returns
HistogramAggregationBase: returns this so that calls can be chained
Example
const agg = esb.histogramAggregation('prices', 'price', 50).minDocCount(1);
▸ extendedBounds(min, max)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/histogram-aggregation-base.js

Set's the range/bounds for the histogram aggregation. Useful when you want to include buckets that might be outside the bounds of indexed documents.

extendedBounds(min: (number | string), max: (number | string)): HistogramAggregationBase
Parameters
min ((number | string)) Start bound / minimum bound value For histogram aggregation, Integer value can be used. For Date histogram, date expression can be used. Available expressions for interval: year, quarter, month, week, day, hour, minute, second
max ((number | string)) End bound / maximum bound value For histogram aggregation, Integer value can be used. For Date histogram, date expression can be used. Available expressions for interval: year, quarter, month, week, day, hour, minute, second
Returns
HistogramAggregationBase: returns this so that calls can be chained
Example
const agg = esb.histogramAggregation('prices', 'price', 50).extendedBounds(0, 500);
▸ hardBounds(min, max)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/histogram-aggregation-base.js

Set's the range/bounds for the histogram aggregation. Useful when you want to limit the range of buckets in the histogram. It is particularly useful in the case of open data ranges that can result in a very large number of buckets. NOTE: Only available in Elasticsearch v7.10.0+

hardBounds(min: (number | string), max: (number | string)): HistogramAggregationBase
Parameters
min ((number | string)) Start bound / minimum bound value For histogram aggregation, Integer value can be used. For Date histogram, date expression can be used. Available expressions for interval: year, quarter, month, week, day, hour, minute, second
max ((number | string)) End bound / maximum bound value For histogram aggregation, Integer value can be used. For Date histogram, date expression can be used. Available expressions for interval: year, quarter, month, week, day, hour, minute, second
Returns
HistogramAggregationBase: returns this so that calls can be chained
Example
const agg = esb.histogramAggregation('prices', 'price', 50).hardBounds(0, 500);
▸ missing(value)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/histogram-aggregation-base.js

Sets the missing parameter which defines how documents that are missing a value should be treated.

missing(value: string): HistogramAggregationBase
Parameters
value (string)
Returns
HistogramAggregationBase: returns this so that calls can be chained
Example
const agg = esb.histogramAggregation('quantity', 'quantity', 10).missing(0);
▸ keyed(keyed)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/histogram-aggregation-base.js

Enable the response to be returned as a keyed object where the key is the bucket interval.

keyed(keyed: boolean): HistogramAggregationBase
Parameters
keyed (boolean) To enable keyed response or not.
Returns
HistogramAggregationBase: returns this so that calls can be chained
Example
const agg = esb.dateHistogramAggregation('sales_over_time', 'date', '1M')
    .keyed(true)
    .format('yyyy-MM-dd');

DateHistogramAggregation

src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/date-histogram-aggregation.js

A multi-bucket aggregation similar to the histogram except it can only be applied on date values. The interval can be specified by date/time expressions.

Elasticsearch reference

new DateHistogramAggregation(name: string, field: string?, interval: string?)

Extends HistogramAggregationBase

Parameters
name (string) The name which will be used to refer to this aggregation.
field (string?) The field to aggregate on
interval (string?) Interval to generate histogram over. Available expressions for interval: year, quarter, month, week, day, hour, minute, second
Example
const agg = esb.dateHistogramAggregation('sales_over_time', 'date', 'month');
const agg = esb.dateHistogramAggregation(
    'sales_over_time',
    'date',
    '1M'
).format('yyyy-MM-dd');
Instance Members
▸ timeZone(tz)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/date-histogram-aggregation.js

Date-times are stored in Elasticsearch in UTC. By default, all bucketing and rounding is also done in UTC. The time_zone parameter can be used to indicate that bucketing should use a different time zone. Sets the date time zone

timeZone(tz: string): DateHistogramAggregation
Parameters
tz (string) Time zone. Time zones may either be specified as an ISO 8601 UTC offset (e.g. +01:00 or -08:00) or as a timezone id, an identifier used in the TZ database like America/Los_Angeles.
Returns
DateHistogramAggregation: returns this so that calls can be chained
Example
const agg = esb.dateHistogramAggregation('by_day', 'date', 'day').timeZone(
    '-01:00'
);
▸ calendarInterval(interval)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/date-histogram-aggregation.js

Calendar-aware intervals are configured with the calendarInterval parameter. The combined interval field for date histograms is deprecated from ES 7.2.

calendarInterval(interval: string): DateHistogramAggregation
Parameters
interval (string) Interval to generate histogram over. You can specify calendar intervals using the unit name, such as month, or as a single unit quantity, such as 1M. For example, day and 1d are equivalent. Multiple quantities, such as 2d, are not supported.
Returns
DateHistogramAggregation: returns this so that calls can be chained
Example
const agg = esb.dateHistogramAggregation('by_month', 'date').calendarInterval(
    'month'
);
▸ fixedInterval(interval)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/date-histogram-aggregation.js

Fixed intervals are configured with the fixedInterval parameter. The combined interval field for date histograms is deprecated from ES 7.2.

fixedInterval(interval: string): DateHistogramAggregation
Parameters
interval (string) Interval to generate histogram over. Intervals are a fixed number of SI units and never deviate, regardless of where they fall on the calendar. However, it means fixed intervals cannot express other units such as months, since the duration of a month is not a fixed quantity.
Returns
DateHistogramAggregation: returns this so that calls can be chained
Example
const agg = esb.dateHistogramAggregation('by_minute', 'date').calendarInterval(
    '60s'
);

The accepted units for fixed intervals are:
millseconds (ms), seconds (s), minutes (m), hours (h) and days (d).

RangeAggregationBase

src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/range-aggregation-base.js

The RangeAggregationBase provides support for common options used across various range Aggregation implementations like Range Aggregation and Date Range aggregation.

NOTE: Instantiating this directly should not be required. However, if you wish to add a custom implementation for whatever reason, this class could be extended.

new RangeAggregationBase(name: string, aggType: string, field: string?)

Extends BucketAggregationBase

Parameters
name (string) The name which will be used to refer to this aggregation.
aggType (string) Type of aggregation
field (string?) The field to aggregate on
Instance Members
▸ format(fmt)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/range-aggregation-base.js

Sets the format expression for key_as_string in response buckets. If no format is specified, then it will use the format specified in the field mapping.

format(fmt: string): RangeAggregationBase
Parameters
fmt (string) Supports expressive date format pattern for Date Histograms
Returns
RangeAggregationBase: returns this so that calls can be chained
▸ range(range)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/range-aggregation-base.js

Adds a range to the list of existing range expressions.

range(range: Object): RangeAggregationBase
Parameters
range (Object) Range to aggregate over. Valid keys are from , to and key
Returns
RangeAggregationBase: returns this so that calls can be chained
Throws
  • TypeError: If range is not an instance of object
  • Error: If none of the required keys, from , to or mask (for IP range) is passed
▸ ranges(ranges)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/range-aggregation-base.js

Adds the list of ranges to the list of existing range expressions.

ranges(ranges: Array<Object>): RangeAggregationBase
Parameters
ranges (Array<Object>) Ranges to aggregate over. Each item must be an object with keys from , to and key .
Returns
RangeAggregationBase: returns this so that calls can be chained
Throws
  • TypeError: If ranges is not an instance of an array or and item in the array is not an instance of object
  • Error: If none of the required keys, from , to or mask (for IP range) is passed
▸ missing(value)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/range-aggregation-base.js

Sets the missing parameter ehich defines how documents that are missing a value should be treated.

missing(value: string): RangeAggregationBase
Parameters
value (string)
Returns
RangeAggregationBase: returns this so that calls can be chained
▸ keyed(keyed)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/range-aggregation-base.js

Enable the response to be returned as a keyed object where the key is the bucket interval.

keyed(keyed: boolean): RangeAggregationBase
Parameters
keyed (boolean) To enable keyed response or not.
Returns
RangeAggregationBase: returns this so that calls can be chained
Example
const agg = esb.dateRangeAggregation('range', 'date')
    .format('MM-yyy')
    .ranges([{ to: 'now-10M/M' }, { from: 'now-10M/M' }])
    .keyed(true);
const agg = esb.geoDistanceAggregation('rings_around_amsterdam', 'location')
    .origin(esb.geoPoint().string('52.3760, 4.894'))
    .ranges([
        { to: 100000, key: 'first_ring' },
        { from: 100000, to: 300000, key: 'second_ring' },
        { from: 300000, key: 'third_ring' }
    ])
    .keyed(true);
▸ toJSON()
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/range-aggregation-base.js

Override default toJSON to return DSL representation for the aggregation query.

toJSON(): Object
Returns
Object: returns an Object which maps to the elasticsearch query DSL

DateRangeAggregation

src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/date-range-aggregation.js

A range aggregation that is dedicated for date values. The main difference between this aggregation and the normal range aggregation is that the from and to values can be expressed in Date Math expressions, and it is also possible to specify a date format by which the from and to response fields will be returned.

Elasticsearch reference

new DateRangeAggregation(name: string, field: string?)

Extends RangeAggregationBase

Parameters
name (string) The name which will be used to refer to this aggregation.
field (string?) The field to aggregate on
Example
const agg = esb.dateRangeAggregation('range', 'date')
    .format('MM-yyy')
    .ranges([{ to: 'now-10M/M' }, { from: 'now-10M/M' }]);
Instance Members
▸ timeZone(tz)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/date-range-aggregation.js

Sets the date time zone. Date-times are stored in Elasticsearch in UTC. By default, all bucketing and rounding is also done in UTC. The time_zone parameter can be used to indicate that bucketing should use a different time zone.

timeZone(tz: string): DateRangeAggregation
Parameters
tz (string) Time zone. Time zones may either be specified as an ISO 8601 UTC offset (e.g. +01:00 or -08:00) or as a timezone id, an identifier used in the TZ database like America/Los_Angeles.
Returns
DateRangeAggregation: returns this so that calls can be chained
Example
const agg = esb.dateRangeAggregation('range', 'date')
    .timeZone('CET')
    .ranges([
        { to: '2016/02/01' },
        { from: '2016/02/01', to: 'now/d' },
        { from: 'now/d' }
    ]);

DiversifiedSamplerAggregation

src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/diversified-sampler-aggregation.js

A filtering aggregation used to limit any sub aggregations' processing to a sample of the top-scoring documents. Diversity settings are used to limit the number of matches that share a common value such as an "author".

Elasticsearch reference

new DiversifiedSamplerAggregation(name: string, field: string?)

Extends BucketAggregationBase

Parameters
name (string) The name which will be used to refer to this aggregation.
field (string?) The field to aggregate on
Example
const reqBody = esb.requestBodySearch()
    .query(esb.queryStringQuery('tags:elasticsearch'))
    .agg(
        esb.diversifiedSamplerAggregation('my_unbiased_sample', 'author')
            .shardSize(200)
            .agg(
                esb.significantTermsAggregation(
                    'keywords',
                    'tags'
                ).exclude(['elasticsearch'])
            )
    );
// Use a script to produce a hash of the multiple values in a tags field
// to ensure we don't have a sample that consists of the same repeated
// combinations of tags
const reqBody = esb.requestBodySearch()
    .query(esb.queryStringQuery('tags:kibana'))
    .agg(
        esb.diversifiedSamplerAggregation('my_unbiased_sample')
            .shardSize(200)
            .maxDocsPerValue(3)
            .script(esb.script('inline', "doc['tags'].values.hashCode()"))
            .agg(
                esb.significantTermsAggregation(
                    'keywords',
                    'tags'
                ).exclude(['kibana'])
            )
    );
Instance Members
▸ shardSize(size)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/diversified-sampler-aggregation.js

The shard_size parameter limits how many top-scoring documents are collected in the sample processed on each shard. The default value is 100.

shardSize(size: number): DiversifiedSamplerAggregation
Parameters
size (number) Maximum number of documents to return from each shard(Integer)
Returns
DiversifiedSamplerAggregation: returns this so that calls can be chained
▸ maxDocsPerValue(maxDocsPerValue)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/diversified-sampler-aggregation.js

Used to control the maximum number of documents collected on any one shard which share a common value. Applies on a per-shard basis only for the purposes of shard-local sampling.

maxDocsPerValue(maxDocsPerValue: number): DiversifiedSamplerAggregation
Parameters
maxDocsPerValue (number) Default 1.(Integer)
Returns
DiversifiedSamplerAggregation: returns this so that calls can be chained
▸ executionHint(hint)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/diversified-sampler-aggregation.js

This setting can influence the management of the values used for de-duplication. Each option will hold up to shard_size values in memory while performing de-duplication but the type of value held can be controlled

executionHint(hint: string): DiversifiedSamplerAggregation
Parameters
hint (string) the possible values are map , global_ordinals , global_ordinals_hash and global_ordinals_low_cardinality
Returns
DiversifiedSamplerAggregation: returns this so that calls can be chained
Throws
  • Error: If Execution Hint is outside the accepted set.

FilterAggregation

src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/filter-aggregation.js

Defines a single bucket of all the documents in the current document set context that match a specified filter. Often this will be used to narrow down the current aggregation context to a specific set of documents.

Elasticsearch reference

new FilterAggregation(name: string, filterQuery: Query?)

Extends BucketAggregationBase

Parameters
name (string) The name which will be used to refer to this aggregation.
filterQuery (Query?) Query to filter on. Example - term query.
Example
const reqBody = esb.requestBodySearch()
    .agg(
        esb.filterAggregation(
            't_shirts',
            esb.termQuery('type', 't-shirt')
        ).agg(esb.avgAggregation('avg_price', 'price'))
    )
    .size(0);
Instance Members
▸ field()
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/filter-aggregation.js
field()
Throws
  • Error: This method cannot be called on FilterAggregation
▸ script()
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/filter-aggregation.js
script()
Throws
  • Error: This method cannot be called on FilterAggregation
▸ filter(filterQuery)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/filter-aggregation.js

Set the filter query for Filter Aggregation.

filter(filterQuery: Query): FilterAggregation
Parameters
filterQuery (Query) Query to filter on. Example - term query.
Returns
FilterAggregation: returns this so that calls can be chained
Throws
  • TypeError: If filterQuery is not an instance of Query

FiltersAggregation

src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/filters-aggregation.js

Defines a single bucket of all the documents in the current document set context that match a specified filter. Often this will be used to narrow down the current aggregation context to a specific set of documents.

Elasticsearch reference

new FiltersAggregation(name: string)

Extends BucketAggregationBase

Parameters
name (string) The name which will be used to refer to this aggregation.
Example
const agg = esb.filtersAggregation('messages')
    .filter('errors', esb.matchQuery('body', 'error'))
    .filter('warnings', esb.matchQuery('body', 'warning'));
const agg = esb.filtersAggregation('messages')
    .anonymousFilters([
        esb.matchQuery('body', 'error'),
        esb.matchQuery('body', 'warning')
    ])
Instance Members
▸ field()
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/filters-aggregation.js
field()
Throws
  • Error: This method cannot be called on FiltersAggregation
▸ script()
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/filters-aggregation.js
script()
Throws
  • Error: This method cannot be called on FiltersAggregation
▸ filter(bucketName, filterQuery)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/filters-aggregation.js

Sets a named filter query. Does not mix with anonymous filters. If anonymous filters are present, they will be overwritten.

filter(bucketName: string, filterQuery: Query): FiltersAggregation
Parameters
bucketName (string) Name for bucket which will collect all documents that match its associated filter.
filterQuery (Query) Query to filter on. Example - term query.
Returns
FiltersAggregation: returns this so that calls can be chained
Throws
  • TypeError: If filterQuery is not an instance of Query
▸ filters(filterQueries)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/filters-aggregation.js

Assigns filters to already added filters. Does not mix with anonymous filters. If anonymous filters are present, they will be overwritten.

filters(filterQueries: Object): FiltersAggregation
Parameters
filterQueries (Object) Object with multiple key value pairs where bucket name is the key and filter query is the value.
Returns
FiltersAggregation: returns this so that calls can be chained
Throws
  • TypeError: If filterQueries is not an instance of object
▸ anonymousFilter(filterQuery)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/filters-aggregation.js

Appends an anonymous filter query. Does not mix with named filters. If named filters are present, they will be overwritten.

anonymousFilter(filterQuery: any): FiltersAggregation
Parameters
filterQuery (any) Query to filter on. Example - term query.
Returns
FiltersAggregation: returns this so that calls can be chained
Throws
  • TypeError: If filterQuery is not an instance of Query
▸ anonymousFilters(filterQueries)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/filters-aggregation.js

Appends an array of anonymous filters. Does not mix with named filters. If named filters are present, they will be overwritten.

anonymousFilters(filterQueries: any): FiltersAggregation
Parameters
filterQueries (any) Array of queries to filter on and generate buckets. Example - term query.
Returns
FiltersAggregation: returns this so that calls can be chained
Throws
  • TypeError: If filterQueries is not an instance of Array
▸ otherBucket(enable, otherBucketKey?)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/filters-aggregation.js

Adds a bucket to the response which will contain all documents that do not match any of the given filters. Returns the other bucket bucket either in a bucket (named _other_ by default) if named filters are being used, or as the last bucket if anonymous filters are being used

otherBucket(enable: boolean, otherBucketKey: string?): FiltersAggregation
Parameters
enable (boolean) True to return other bucket with documents that do not match any filters and False to disable computation
otherBucketKey (string?) Optional key for the other bucket. Default is _other_ .
Returns
FiltersAggregation: returns this so that calls can be chained
▸ otherBucketKey(otherBucketKey)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/filters-aggregation.js

Sets the key for the other bucket to a value other than the default _other_. Setting this parameter will implicitly set the other_bucket parameter to true. If anonymous filters are being used, setting this parameter will not make sense.

otherBucketKey(otherBucketKey: string): FiltersAggregation
Parameters
otherBucketKey (string)
Returns
FiltersAggregation: returns this so that calls can be chained
Example
const agg = esb.filtersAggregation('messages')
    .filter('errors', esb.matchQuery('body', 'error'))
    .filter('warnings', esb.matchQuery('body', 'warning'))
    .otherBucketKey('other_messages');

GeoDistanceAggregation

src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/geo-distance-aggregation.js

A multi-bucket aggregation that works on geo_point fields and conceptually works very similar to the range aggregation. The user can define a point of origin and a set of distance range buckets. The aggregation evaluate the distance of each document value from the origin point and determines the buckets it belongs to based on the ranges (a document belongs to a bucket if the distance between the document and the origin falls within the distance range of the bucket).

Elasticsearch reference

new GeoDistanceAggregation(name: string, field: string?)

Extends RangeAggregationBase

Parameters
name (string) The name which will be used to refer to this aggregation.
field (string?) The field to aggregate on
Example
const agg = esb.geoDistanceAggregation('rings_around_amsterdam', 'location')
    .origin(esb.geoPoint().string('52.3760, 4.894'))
    .ranges([{ to: 100000 }, { from: 100000, to: 300000 }, { from: 300000 }]);
Instance Members
▸ format()
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/geo-distance-aggregation.js
format()
Throws
  • Error: This method cannot be called on GeoDistanceAggregation
▸ script()
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/geo-distance-aggregation.js
script()
Throws
  • Error: This method cannot be called on GeoDistanceAggregation
▸ origin(point)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/geo-distance-aggregation.js

Sets the point of origin from where distances will be measured.

origin(point: GeoPoint): GeoDistanceAggregation
Parameters
point (GeoPoint) A valid GeoPoint object.
Returns
GeoDistanceAggregation: returns this so that calls can be chained
Throws
  • TypeError: If point is not an instance of GeoPoint
▸ unit(unit)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/geo-distance-aggregation.js

Sets the distance unit. Valid values are: mi (miles), in (inches), yd (yards), km (kilometers), cm (centimeters), mm (millimeters), ft(feet), NM(nauticalmiles)

unit(unit: string): GeoDistanceAggregation
Parameters
unit (string) Distance unit, default is m (meters).
Returns
GeoDistanceAggregation: returns this so that calls can be chained
Throws
  • Error: If Unit is outside the accepted set.
Example
const agg = esb.geoDistanceAggregation('rings_around_amsterdam', 'location')
    .origin(esb.geoPoint().string('52.3760, 4.894'))
    .unit('km')
    .ranges([{ to: 100 }, { from: 100, to: 300 }, { from: 300 }]);
▸ distanceType(type)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/geo-distance-aggregation.js

Sets the distance calculation mode, arc or plane. The arc calculation is the more accurate. The plane is the faster but least accurate.

distanceType(type: string): GeoDistanceAggregation
Parameters
type (string)
Returns
GeoDistanceAggregation: returns this so that calls can be chained
Throws
  • Error: If type is neither plane nor arc .
Example
const agg = esb.geoDistanceAggregation('rings_around_amsterdam', 'location')
    .origin(esb.geoPoint().string('52.3760, 4.894'))
    .unit('km')
    .distanceType('plane')
    .ranges([{ to: 100 }, { from: 100, to: 300 }, { from: 300 }]);

GeoHashGridAggregation

src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/geo-hash-grid-aggregation.js

A multi-bucket aggregation that works on geo_point fields and groups points into buckets that represent cells in a grid. The resulting grid can be sparse and only contains cells that have matching data. Each cell is labeled using a geohash which is of user-definable precision.

Elasticsearch reference

new GeoHashGridAggregation(name: string, field: string?)

Extends BucketAggregationBase

Parameters
name (string) The name which will be used to refer to this aggregation.
field (string?) The field to aggregate on
Example
const agg = esb.geoHashGridAggregation('large-grid', 'location').precision(3);
Instance Members
▸ format()
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/geo-hash-grid-aggregation.js
format()
Throws
  • Error: This method cannot be called on GeoHashGridAggregation
▸ script()
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/geo-hash-grid-aggregation.js
script()
Throws
  • Error: This method cannot be called on GeoHashGridAggregation
▸ precision(precision)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/geo-hash-grid-aggregation.js

Sets the precision for the generated geohash.

precision(precision: number): GeoHashGridAggregation
Parameters
precision (number) Precision can be between 1 and 12
Returns
GeoHashGridAggregation: returns this so that calls can be chained
Throws
  • Error: If precision is not between 1 and 12.
▸ size(size)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/geo-hash-grid-aggregation.js

Sets the maximum number of geohash buckets to return. When results are trimmed, buckets are prioritised based on the volumes of documents they contain.

size(size: number): GeoHashGridAggregation
Parameters
size (number) Optional. The maximum number of geohash buckets to return (defaults to 10,000).
Returns
GeoHashGridAggregation: returns this so that calls can be chained
▸ shardSize(shardSize)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/geo-hash-grid-aggregation.js

Determines how many geohash_grid the coordinating node will request from each shard.

shardSize(shardSize: number): GeoHashGridAggregation
Parameters
shardSize (number) Optional.
Returns
GeoHashGridAggregation: returns this so that calls can be chained

GlobalAggregation

src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/global-aggregation.js

Defines a single bucket of all the documents within the search execution context. This context is defined by the indices and the document types you’re searching on, but is not influenced by the search query itself.

Elasticsearch reference

new GlobalAggregation(name: string)

Extends BucketAggregationBase

Parameters
name (string) The name which will be used to refer to this aggregation.
Example
const reqBody = esb.requestBodySearch()
    .query(esb.matchQuery('type', 't-shirt'))
    .agg(
        esb.globalAggregation('all_products').agg(
            esb.avgAggregation('avg_price', 'price')
        )
    )
    .agg(esb.avgAggregation('t_shirts', 'price'));
Instance Members
▸ field()
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/global-aggregation.js
field()
Throws
  • Error: This method cannot be called on GlobalAggregation
▸ script()
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/global-aggregation.js
script()
Throws
  • Error: This method cannot be called on GlobalAggregation

HistogramAggregation

src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/histogram-aggregation.js

A multi-bucket values source based aggregation that can be applied on numeric values extracted from the documents. It dynamically builds fixed size (a.k.a. interval) buckets over the values.

Elasticsearch reference

new HistogramAggregation(name: string, field: string?, interval: number?)

Extends HistogramAggregationBase

Parameters
name (string) The name which will be used to refer to this aggregation.
field (string?) The field to aggregate on
interval (number?) Interval to generate histogram over.
Example
const agg = esb.histogramAggregation('prices', 'price', 50);
const agg = esb.histogramAggregation('prices', 'price', 50).minDocCount(1);
const agg = esb.histogramAggregation('prices', 'price', 50)
    .extendedBounds(0, 500);
const agg = esb.histogramAggregation('quantity', 'quantity', 10).missing(0);

IpRangeAggregation

src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/ip-range-aggregation.js

Dedicated range aggregation for IP typed fields.

Elasticsearch reference

new IpRangeAggregation(name: string, field: string?)

Extends RangeAggregationBase

Parameters
name (string) The name which will be used to refer to this aggregation.
field (string?) The field to aggregate on
Example
const agg = esb.ipRangeAggregation('ip_ranges', 'ip').ranges([
    { to: '10.0.0.5' },
    { from: '10.0.0.5' }
]);
const agg = esb.ipRangeAggregation('ip_ranges', 'ip').ranges([
    { mask: '10.0.0.0/25' },
    { mask: '10.0.0.127/25' }
]);
Instance Members

Throws
  • Error: This method cannot be called on IpRangeAggregation

MissingAggregation

src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/missing-aggregation.js

A field data based single bucket aggregation, that creates a bucket of all documents in the current document set context that are missing a field value (effectively, missing a field or having the configured NULL value set).

Elasticsearch reference

new MissingAggregation(name: string, field: string?)

Extends BucketAggregationBase

Parameters
name (string) The name which will be used to refer to this aggregation.
field (string?) The field to aggregate on
Example
const agg = esb.missingAggregation('products_without_a_price', 'price');

Throws
  • Error: This method cannot be called on MissingAggregation

NestedAggregation

src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/nested-aggregation.js

A special single bucket aggregation that enables aggregating nested documents.

Elasticsearch reference

new NestedAggregation(name: string, path: string?)

Extends BucketAggregationBase

Parameters
name (string) The name which will be used to refer to this aggregation.
path (string?) path of the nested document
Example
const reqBody = esb.requestBodySearch()
    .query(esb.matchQuery('name', 'led tv'))
    .agg(
        esb.nestedAggregation('resellers', 'resellers').agg(
            esb.minAggregation('min_price', 'resellers.price')
        )
    );

Sets the nested path

path(path: string): NestedAggregation
Parameters
path (string) path of the nested document
Returns
NestedAggregation: returns this so that calls can be chained

ParentAggregation

src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/parent-aggregation.js

A special single bucket aggregation that enables aggregating from buckets on child document types to buckets on parent documents.

This aggregation relies on the _parent field in the mapping.

Elasticsearch reference

new ParentAggregation(name: string, type: string?)

Extends BucketAggregationBase

Parameters
name (string) The name which will be used to refer to this aggregation.
type (string?) The type of the child document.
Example
const reqBody = esb.requestBodySearch()
    .agg(
        esb.termsAggregation('top-names', 'owner.display_name.keyword')
            .size(10)
            .agg(
                esb.parentAggregation('to-questions')
                    .type('answer')
                    .agg(
                        esb.termsAggregation(
                            'top-tags',
                            'tags.keyword'
                        ).size(10)
                    )
            )
    )
    .size(0);
Instance Members
▸ field()
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/parent-aggregation.js
field()
Throws
  • Error: This method cannot be called on ParentAggregation
▸ script()
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/parent-aggregation.js
script()
Throws
  • Error: This method cannot be called on ParentAggregation
▸ type(type)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/parent-aggregation.js

Sets the child type/mapping for aggregation.

type(type: string): ParentAggregation
Parameters
type (string) The child type that the buckets in the parent space should be mapped to.
Returns
ParentAggregation: returns this so that calls can be chained

RangeAggregation

src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/range-aggregation.js

A multi-bucket value source based aggregation that enables the user to define a set of ranges - each representing a bucket. During the aggregation process, the values extracted from each document will be checked against each bucket range and "bucket" the relevant/matching document.

Note that this aggregration includes the from value and excludes the to value for each range.

Elasticsearch reference

new RangeAggregation(name: string, field: string?)

Extends RangeAggregationBase

Parameters
name (string) The name which will be used to refer to this aggregation.
field (string?) The field to aggregate on
Example
const agg = esb.rangeAggregation('price_ranges', 'price').ranges([
    { to: 50 },
    { from: 50, to: 100 },
    { from: 100 }
]);
const agg = esb.rangeAggregation('price_ranges')
    .script(esb.script('inline', "doc['price'].value").lang('painless'))
    .ranges([{ to: 50 }, { from: 50, to: 100 }, { from: 100 }]);
// Value script for on-the-fly conversion before aggregation
const agg = esb.rangeAggregation('price_ranges', 'price')
    .script(
        esb.script('inline', '_value * params.conversion_rate')
            .lang('painless')
            .params({ conversion_rate: 0.8 })
    )
    .ranges([{ to: 50 }, { from: 50, to: 100 }, { from: 100 }]);
// Compute statistics over the prices in each price range
const agg = esb.rangeAggregation('price_ranges', 'price')
    .ranges([{ to: 50 }, { from: 50, to: 100 }, { from: 100 }])
    // Passing price to Stats Aggregation is optional(same value source)
    .agg(esb.statsAggregation('price_stats', 'price'));

RareTermsAggregation

src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/rare-terms-aggregation.js

A multi-bucket value source based aggregation which finds "rare" terms — terms that are at the long-tail of the distribution and are not frequent. Conceptually, this is like a terms aggregation that is sorted by _count ascending. As noted in the terms aggregation docs, actually ordering a terms agg by count ascending has unbounded error. Instead, you should use the rare_terms aggregation

Elasticsearch reference

NOTE: Only available in Elasticsearch 7.3.0+.

new RareTermsAggregation(name: string, field: string)

Extends BucketAggregationBase

Parameters
name (string) The name which will be used to refer to this aggregation.
field (string) The field we wish to find rare terms in
Example
const agg = esb.rareTermsAggregation('genres', 'genre');
Instance Members
▸ maxDocCount(maxDocCnt)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/rare-terms-aggregation.js

Sets the maximum number of documents a term should appear in.

maxDocCount(maxDocCnt: number): RareTermsAggregation
Parameters
maxDocCnt (number) Integer value for maximum number of documents a term should appear in. Max doc count can be between 1 and 100.
Returns
RareTermsAggregation: returns this so that calls can be chained
Example
const agg = esb.rareTermsAggregation('genres', 'genre').maxDocCount(2);
▸ precision(precision)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/rare-terms-aggregation.js

Sets the precision of the internal CuckooFilters. Smaller precision leads to better approximation, but higher memory usage. Cannot be smaller than 0.00001

precision(precision: number): RareTermsAggregation
Parameters
precision (number) Float value for precision of the internal CuckooFilters. Default is 0.01
Returns
RareTermsAggregation: returns this so that calls can be chained
Example
const agg = esb.rareTermsAggregation('genres', 'genre').precision(0.001);
▸ include(include)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/rare-terms-aggregation.js

Sets terms that should be included in the aggregation

include(include: string): RareTermsAggregation
Parameters
include (string) Regular expression that will determine what values are "allowed" to be aggregated
Returns
RareTermsAggregation: returns this so that calls can be chained
Example
const agg = esb.rareTermsAggregation('genres', 'genre').include('swi*');
▸ exclude(exclude)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/rare-terms-aggregation.js

Sets terms that should be excluded from the aggregation

exclude(exclude: string): RareTermsAggregation
Parameters
exclude (string) Regular expression that will determine what values should not be aggregated
Returns
RareTermsAggregation: returns this so that calls can be chained
Example
const agg = esb.rareTermsAggregation('genres', 'genre').exclude('electro*');
▸ missing(value)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/rare-terms-aggregation.js

Sets the missing parameter which defines how documents that are missing a value should be treated.

missing(value: string): RareTermsAggregation
Parameters
value (string)
Returns
RareTermsAggregation: returns this so that calls can be chained
▸ script()

script()
Throws
  • Error: This method cannot be called on RareTermsAggregation

ReverseNestedAggregation

src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/reverse-nested-aggregation.js

A special single bucket aggregation that enables aggregating on parent docs from nested documents. Effectively this aggregation can break out of the nested block structure and link to other nested structures or the root document, which allows nesting other aggregations that aren’t part of the nested object in a nested aggregation.

The reverse_nested aggregation must be defined inside a nested aggregation.

Elasticsearch reference

new ReverseNestedAggregation(name: string, path: string?)

Extends BucketAggregationBase

Parameters
name (string) The name which will be used to refer to this aggregation.
path (string?) Defines to what nested object field should be joined back. The default is empty, which means that it joins back to the root / main document level.
Example
const reqBody = esb.requestBodySearch()
    .query(esb.matchQuery('name', 'led tv'))
    .agg(
        esb.nestedAggregation('comments', 'comments').agg(
            esb.termsAggregation('top_usernames', 'comments.username').agg(
                esb.reverseNestedAggregation('comment_to_issue').agg(
                    esb.termsAggregation('top_tags_per_comment', 'tags')
                )
            )
        )
    );
Instance Members
▸ field()
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/reverse-nested-aggregation.js
field()
Throws
  • Error: This method cannot be called on ReverseNestedAggregation
▸ script()
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/reverse-nested-aggregation.js
script()
Throws
  • Error: This method cannot be called on ReverseNestedAggregation
▸ path(path)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/reverse-nested-aggregation.js

Sets the level to join back for subsequent aggregations in a multiple layered nested object types

path(path: string): ReverseNestedAggregation
Parameters
path (string) Defines to what nested object field should be joined back. The default is empty, which means that it joins back to the root / main document level.
Returns
ReverseNestedAggregation: returns this so that calls can be chained

SamplerAggregation

src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/sampler-aggregation.js

A filtering aggregation used to limit any sub aggregations' processing to a sample of the top-scoring documents.

Elasticsearch reference

new SamplerAggregation(name: string, field: string?)

Extends BucketAggregationBase

Parameters
name (string) The name which will be used to refer to this aggregation.
field (string?) The field to aggregate on
Example
const reqBody = esb.requestBodySearch()
    .query(esb.queryStringQuery('tags:kibana OR tags:javascript'))
    .agg(
        esb.samplerAggregation('sample')
            .shardSize(200)
            .agg(
                esb.significantTermsAggregation(
                    'keywords',
                    'tags'
                ).exclude(['kibana', 'javascript'])
            )
    );
Instance Members
▸ field()
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/sampler-aggregation.js
field()
Throws
  • Error: This method cannot be called on SamplerAggregation
▸ script()
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/sampler-aggregation.js
script()
Throws
  • Error: This method cannot be called on SamplerAggregation
▸ shardSize(size)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/sampler-aggregation.js

The shard_size parameter limits how many top-scoring documents are collected in the sample processed on each shard. The default value is 100.

shardSize(size: number): SamplerAggregation
Parameters
size (number) Maximum number of documents to return from each shard(Integer)
Returns
SamplerAggregation: returns this so that calls can be chained

TermsAggregationBase

src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/terms-aggregation-base.js

The TermsAggregationBase provides support for common options used across various terms Aggregation implementations like Significant terms and Terms aggregation.

NOTE: Instantiating this directly should not be required. However, if you wish to add a custom implementation for whatever reason, this class could be extended.

new TermsAggregationBase(name: string, aggType: string, refUrl: string, field: string?)

Extends BucketAggregationBase

Parameters
name (string) The name which will be used to refer to this aggregation.
aggType (string) Type of aggregation
refUrl (string) Elasticsearch reference URL.
field (string?) The field to aggregate on
Instance Members
▸ format(fmt)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/terms-aggregation-base.js

Sets the format expression for key_as_string in response buckets. If no format is specified, then it will use the first format specified in the field mapping.

format(fmt: string): TermsAggregationBase
Parameters
fmt (string) Format mask to apply on aggregation response. Example: ####.00.
Returns
TermsAggregationBase: returns this so that calls can be chained
▸ minDocCount(minDocCnt)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/terms-aggregation-base.js

Sets the minimum number of matching hits required to return the terms.

minDocCount(minDocCnt: number): TermsAggregationBase
Parameters
minDocCnt (number) Integer value for minimum number of documents required to return bucket in response
Returns
TermsAggregationBase: returns this so that calls can be chained
Example
const agg = esb.significantTermsAggregation('tags', 'tag').minDocCount(10);
▸ shardMinDocCount(minDocCnt)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/terms-aggregation-base.js

Sets the parameter which regulates the certainty a shard has if the term should actually be added to the candidate list or not with respect to the min_doc_count. Terms will only be considered if their local shard frequency within the set is higher than the shard_min_doc_count.

shardMinDocCount(minDocCnt: number): TermsAggregationBase
Parameters
minDocCnt (number) Sets the shard_min_doc_count parameter. Default is 1 and has no effect unless you explicitly set it.
Returns
TermsAggregationBase: returns this so that calls can be chained
▸ size(size)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/terms-aggregation-base.js

Defines how many term buckets should be returned out of the overall terms list.

size(size: number): TermsAggregationBase
Parameters
size (number)
Returns
TermsAggregationBase: returns this so that calls can be chained
Example
const agg = esb.termsAggregation('products', 'product').size(5);
▸ shardSize(size)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/terms-aggregation-base.js

Sets the shard_size parameter to control the volumes of candidate terms produced by each shard. For the default, -1, shard_size will be automatically estimated based on the number of shards and the size parameter.

shard_size cannot be smaller than size (as it doesn’t make much sense). When it is, elasticsearch will override it and reset it to be equal to size.

shardSize(size: number): TermsAggregationBase
Parameters
size (number)
Returns
TermsAggregationBase: returns this so that calls can be chained
▸ missing(value)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/terms-aggregation-base.js

Sets the missing parameter which defines how documents that are missing a value should be treated.

missing(value: string): TermsAggregationBase
Parameters
value (string)
Returns
TermsAggregationBase: returns this so that calls can be chained
▸ include(clause)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/terms-aggregation-base.js

Filter the values for which buckets will be created.

include(clause: (RegExp | Array | string)): TermsAggregationBase
Parameters
clause ((RegExp | Array | string)) Determine what values are "allowed" to be aggregated
Returns
TermsAggregationBase: returns this so that calls can be chained
Example
const agg = esb.termsAggregation('tags', 'tags')
    .include('.*sport.*')
    .exclude('water_.*');
// Match on exact values
const reqBody = esb.requestBodySearch()
    .agg(
        esb.termsAggregation('JapaneseCars', 'make').include([
            'mazda',
            'honda'
        ])
    )
    .agg(
        esb.termsAggregation('ActiveCarManufacturers', 'make').exclude([
            'rover',
            'jensen'
        ])
    );
▸ exclude(clause)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/terms-aggregation-base.js

Filter the values for which buckets will be created.

exclude(clause: (RegExp | Array | string)): TermsAggregationBase
Parameters
clause ((RegExp | Array | string)) Determine the values that should not be aggregated
Returns
TermsAggregationBase: returns this so that calls can be chained
Example
const agg = esb.termsAggregation('tags', 'tags')
    .include('.*sport.*')
    .exclude('water_.*');
// Match on exact values
const reqBody = esb.requestBodySearch()
    .agg(
        esb.termsAggregation('JapaneseCars', 'make').include([
            'mazda',
            'honda'
        ])
    )
    .agg(
        esb.termsAggregation('ActiveCarManufacturers', 'make').exclude([
            'rover',
            'jensen'
        ])
    );
▸ executionHint(hint)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/terms-aggregation-base.js

This setting can influence the management of the values used for de-duplication. Each option will hold up to shard_size values in memory while performing de-duplication but the type of value held can be controlled

executionHint(hint: string): TermsAggregationBase
Parameters
hint (string) the possible values are map , global_ordinals , global_ordinals_hash and global_ordinals_low_cardinality
Returns
TermsAggregationBase: returns this so that calls can be chained
Throws
  • Error: If Execution Hint is outside the accepted set.
Example
const agg = esb.significantTermsAggregation('tags', 'tag').executionHint('map');
const agg = esb.termsAggregation('tags', 'tags').executionHint('map');

SignificantAggregationBase

src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/significant-aggregation-base.js

The SignificantAggregationBase provides support for common options used in SignificantTermsAggregation and SignificantTextAggregation.

NOTE: Instantiating this directly should not be required. However, if you wish to add a custom implementation for whatever reason, this class could be extended.

new SignificantAggregationBase()

Extends TermsAggregationBase

Instance Members
▸ jlh()
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/significant-aggregation-base.js

Use JLH score as significance score.

jlh(): SignificantAggregationBase
Returns
SignificantAggregationBase: returns this so that calls can be chained
▸ mutualInformation(includeNegatives = true, backgroundIsSuperset = true)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/significant-aggregation-base.js

Use mutual_information as significance score

mutualInformation(includeNegatives: boolean?, backgroundIsSuperset: boolean?): SignificantAggregationBase
Parameters
includeNegatives (boolean? = true) Default true . If set to false , filters out the terms that appear less often in the subset than in documents outside the subset
backgroundIsSuperset (boolean? = true) true (default) if the documents in the bucket are also contained in the background. If instead you defined a custom background filter that represents a different set of documents that you want to compare to, pass false
Returns
SignificantAggregationBase: returns this so that calls can be chained
▸ chiSquare(includeNegatives, backgroundIsSuperset)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/significant-aggregation-base.js

Use chi_square as significance score

chiSquare(includeNegatives: boolean, backgroundIsSuperset: boolean): SignificantAggregationBase
Parameters
includeNegatives (boolean = true) Default true . If set to false , filters out the terms that appear less often in the subset than in documents outside the subset
backgroundIsSuperset (boolean = true) true (default) if the documents in the bucket are also contained in the background. If instead you defined a custom background filter that represents a different set of documents that you want to compare to, pass false
Returns
SignificantAggregationBase: returns this so that calls can be chained
▸ gnd(backgroundIsSuperset)

backgroundIsSuperset (boolean = true) true (default) if the documents in the bucket are also contained in the background. If instead you defined a custom background filter that represents a different set of documents that you want to compare to, pass false
Returns
SignificantAggregationBase: returns this so that calls can be chained
▸ percentage()
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/significant-aggregation-base.js

Use a simple calculation of the number of documents in the foreground sample with a term divided by the number of documents in the background with the term. By default this produces a score greater than zero and less than one.

percentage(): SignificantAggregationBase
Returns
SignificantAggregationBase: returns this so that calls can be chained

▸ backgroundFilter(filterQuery)
src/aggregations/bucket-aggregations/significant-aggregation-base.js

Sets the background_filter to narrow the scope of statistical information for background term frequencies instead of using the entire index.

backgroundFilter(filterQuery: Query): SignificantAggregationBase
Parameters
filterQuery (Query) Filter query
Returns
SignificantAggregationBase: returns this so that calls can be chained
Example
const reqBody = esb.requestBodySearch()
    .query(esb.matchQuery('text', 'madrid'))
    .agg(
        esb.significantAggregationBase('tags', 'tag').backgroundFilter(
            esb.termQuery('text', 'spain')
        )
    );
